column4: antique museum hookahs ... or, ... canal? metro stop dubai mall/burj khalifa overpass side road points, walk towards canal ... huge smoke shop along stretch (i pass walk) wall wall shisha pipes etc. name however. also, walk canal pass holiday inn express lovely little bar muchachas (with vegan options) nice margaritas :) happy hour - ladies night (on monday ... late) 'gentlemen's night tuesday!
column5: antique museum also has hookahs ... or, ... have you been to the canal? if you take the metro 1 stop to dubai mall/burj khalifa and go overpass to same side of road as 4 points, and walk towards the canal ... there is a huge smoke shop along this stretch (i pass it when out for a walk) with wall to wall shisha pipes etc. i don't know the name of it however. also, if you walk to the canal you'll pass the holiday inn express and their lovely little bar muchachas (with vegan options) and nice margaritas :) with happy hour 5 - 8 pm and a ladies night (on monday ... too late) but a 'gentlemen's night on tuesday!

column4:
folks,
i'm planning visit march/april next year finish nights phuket fly home from. family kids aged 8. we'll spend 4/5 nights bangkok, khao sok, nights krabi railay phi phi.
i'd something special last nights phuket keep kids happy. budget €150-€350 per night.
my criteria (in order preference) is:
1. nice ambience resort surrounding area (trees, soft lighting etc. concrete jungle)
2. walking distance amenities, mini market, local restaurants etc.
3. good kids pool scene kids club
we done lot beach beachfront seaview dealbreaker. we'll laze resort mostly day trip theme park evening see bright lights patong suitable kids.
i've done lot research looked maps narrowing following list:
dusit thani laguna
centara grand karon
katathani beach resort
the baray villa
any advice folks stayed properties much appreciated. i'm trying sense 'feeling place' i've looked youtube videos locations leads mostly towards dusit thani baray villa.
thanks advance
column5:
hi folks,
i'm planning a visit in march/april next year which will finish with 4 nights in phuket where we fly home from. we are a family of 4 with kids aged 6 and 8. we'll spend 4/5 nights in bangkok, a few in khao sok, then 6 nights each in krabi railay and phi phi.
i'd like something special for the last 4 nights in phuket but also to keep the kids happy. budget is €150-€350 per night.
my criteria (in order of preference) is:
1. nice ambience in resort and surrounding area (trees, soft lighting etc. not concrete jungle)
2. walking distance to some amenities, mini market, local restaurants etc.
3. good kids pool scene and maybe kids club
we will have done a lot of beach stuff already so beachfront or seaview isn't a dealbreaker. we'll laze around the resort mostly and maybe do a day trip to theme park and one evening to see the bright lights of patong if suitable with kids.
i've done a lot of research and looked on maps narrowing down to the following list:
dusit thani laguna
centara grand karon
katathani beach resort
the baray villa
any advice from folks who have stayed one or some of these properties would be much appreciated. what i'm really trying to get a sense of is the 'feeling of a place' i've also looked at youtube videos of locations etc which leads me mostly towards dusit thani or baray villa.
thanks in advance
column8: Phuket resort decision Dusit, Centara, Katathani or Baray

wingham lovely village shops places eat drink.
it’s main bus route canterbury sandwich, regular services, easy visit places bus.
canterbury large public transport hub want afield.
wingham wildlife park little zoo outside village.
no personal experience, dog wingham highly regarded restaurant rooms village centre.
column5:
wingham is a lovely village which still has some shops and places to eat and drink.
it’s on the main bus route between canterbury and sandwich, with regular services, so easy to visit those places by bus.
canterbury is a large public transport hub if you want to go further afield.
wingham wildlife park is a great little zoo just outside the village.
no personal experience, but the dog at wingham is a highly regarded restaurant with rooms in the village centre.

column4:
hello uditi
all sight seeings udaipur less near city palace complex. time energy day evening sunset boat ride lake pichola gives brief stop jag mandir click beautiful photos lake city.
on next day city palace jagdish temple. wonderful vintage car museum garden hotel.. opt interested. evening attend culural dance show bagore ki haveli.
food... typical rajasthani veg thali good garden hotel... place vintage car gallery king udaipur. lunch. day sight seeing lunch gateway restaurant find city palace (tripoliya gate) jagdish temple 1st floor.
dinner must ambrai good view udaipur city night.
happy travelling
rahul - ashoka holidays , jaipur
column5:
hello uditi
all sight seeings of udaipur are more or less near the city palace complex. so if you have time and energy o day one then in the evening you can go for sunset boat ride in lake pichola which also gives you a brief stop at jag mandir from where you can click some very beautiful photos of this lake city.
on next day you can go for city palace and jagdish temple. there is also a wonderful vintage car museum at garden hotel.. you can opt for the same if you are interested. evening you can attend culural dance show at bagore ki haveli.
food... typical rajasthani veg thali is good at garden hotel... same place where we have the vintage car gallery of the king of udaipur. you can go here for lunch. on day of sight seeing you can go for lunch at gateway restaurant which you will find between city palace (tripoliya gate) and jagdish temple on 1st floor.
dinner you must go to ambrai from where you get a good view of the udaipur city at night.
happy travelling
rahul - ashoka holidays , jaipur

column4: stayed stone hedge june 2019 excellent hotel. wonderful architecture large rooms interior. lovely backyard restaurant good variety buffet. hotel came pleasant surprise expect luxury remote place.
column5: i stayed at stone hedge in june 2019 and it is an excellent hotel. wonderful architecture and they have large rooms with great interior. a lovely backyard and the restaurant has a good variety in their buffet. this hotel came as a pleasant surprise as we did not expect such luxury in a remote place.

column4:
personally teenage girls jbr/marina area suit much better.
the conrad excellent hotel tad business orientated, lovely there’s lot going keep teens occupied.
dubai mall isn’t within walking distance it’s taxi ride metro ( walk metro easy enough).
jbr/marina closer theme parks easy enough atlantis there’s lot choice restaurants area lively enough keep occupied.
sheikh zayed rd central getting dubai, there’s plenty cafes fast food places nearby they’re spread dependent taxis head elsewhere evening.
i honestly bed grosvenor house tick boxes it’s half board excellent. it’s way budget i’d inclined look apartment area.
column5:
personally i think with 3 teenage girls jbr/marina area would suit you much better.
the conrad is an excellent hotel if not a tad business orientated, as lovely as it is there’s not a lot going on to keep teens occupied.
dubai mall isn’t really within walking distance and it’s still a taxi ride or metro ( a bit of a walk from the metro but easy enough).
jbr/marina is closer to the theme parks and easy enough to get to atlantis but there’s also a lot more choice for restaurants and the area is lively enough to keep them occupied.
sheikh zayed rd is more central for getting about dubai, there’s plenty of cafes and fast food places nearby but they’re a bit more spread out than and you might be more dependent on taxis to head to elsewhere in the evening.
i honestly think a 1 bed at grosvenor house would tick all of your boxes and it’s half board is excellent. if it’s way over budget then i’d still be inclined to look for another apartment in this area.

column4: curfew am. people usually home 6-7 caught out. shopping complexes closed. open supermarket section people buy food essentials. shops closed except pharmacies. restaurants closed. open takeaway only. street stalls open takeaway only. usually close 6pm. cinemas entertainment venues closed. massage shops, spas, gyms, hairdressers, barbers, etc. closed. public parks, stadiums, sports venues, etc. closed. educational institutes, public venues museums, galleries, etc. closed. train system opersting non-curfew hours much fewer passengers due working home. modes public transport bangkok stopped. included flights, trains, buses.
column5: there is a curfew between 8 pm and 4 am. but people usually are home before 6-7 pm so as not to get caught out. all shopping complexes closed. some open their supermarket section for people to buy food and essentials. most shops are closed except pharmacies. most restaurants are closed. some are open for takeaway only. some street stalls are open for takeaway only. they usually close by 5 or 6pm. all cinemas and entertainment venues closed. all massage shops, spas, gyms, hairdressers, barbers, etc. closed. all public parks, stadiums, sports venues, etc. closed. all educational institutes, public venues such as museums, galleries, etc. closed. train system opersting during non-curfew hours but much fewer passengers to due most working from home. all modes of public transport to and from bangkok stopped. this included flights, trains, buses.

column4:
wonderful months uae (myself two younger kids) wanted share favorite top lists. course loved burj khalifa, wild wadi, etc, lot dubai lower cost "local" memorable. many much easier car. them, particular order: 
1. boats, markets museums historical creek day: much see creek fan walking boating. easily plan trip combining little 1aed abra boats ferries walking. started baniyas, walked souks, crossed souks side (a good time side trip museums there), walked way markets, crossing baniyas canopy hilton is. staying canopy hilton, curio hotel sheraton creek perfect way it. 
2. lovely beaches, playgrounds walking al mamzar beach park: truly hidden gem long walks pretty beach coves, endless playgrounds places grill fly kite. spotless charge 5aed admission well spent facilities. look online see endless stretches sand side park. water clean clear sand softer much dubai.
  3. culture beauty sharjah: trip number times. head museum islamic civilization 30-40 minute visit (if science, fascinating kids liked it, interactive), there, plenty time stop fish market, amazing. head along al noor mosque park there. ideal arrive hour sunset see lovely al noor island lit dark well. wander al noor island explore paths gardens, sculptures, reading pavilion ropes course (there admission fee). after, walk bridge head right, walking along bay, al majaz waterfront. liked playground eating al fanar, emirati restaurant. lovely cool nights water provide blankets. 
4. laser light show festivities festival city: can't remember many times this, ta friend forums suggested it. fun mall, and, saw fountain shows dubai far favorite. every show different evening, whole night it. stunning lasers lights water -- free. something happening fun mall -- festival another, great. holiday inn festival city truly hidden gem. lovely, spacious modern rooms, fantastic staff, kids eat free excellent healthy restaurant. kept going kids #1 place stay dubai (against lof competition places 5x-7x price, it). 
6. getting super posh versace (not cheap day): place returned again! kids roll subdued upscale environment, versace dedicated family pool gorgeous warm excellent food service. versace china poolside? yes, please. big fluffly towels, kids menu pretty garden none crowds experience palm (but beach, never missed it). entrance fee little steep 100% redeemable food drink well worth fancy fancy day kiddos. 
dubai (and uae) place kids. there's much much eat family friendly. loved there!
column5:
we have had a wonderful 5 months in the uae (myself and my two younger kids) and i wanted to share some of my favorite things we did which aren't always on the top of all of the lists. of course we loved the burj khalifa, wild wadi, etc, but there are a lot of other great things to do in dubai which are lower in cost and more "local" which are very memorable. many of them are much easier with a car. here are some of them, not in any particular order: 
1. boats, markets and museums on a historical creek day: there is so much to see on the creek if you are a fan of walking and boating. you can easily plan a trip combining little 1aed abra boats with ferries and walking. we started at baniyas, walked up to the souks, crossed to the other souks on the other side (a good time for side trip to some of the museums there), and walked all of the way down through the markets, crossing back over to baniyas where the canopy by hilton is. staying at the canopy by hilton, or the curio hotel there or the sheraton on the creek is a perfect way to do it. 
2. lovely beaches, playgrounds and walking at al mamzar beach park: this is truly a hidden gem with long walks and pretty beach coves, endless playgrounds and places to grill and fly a kite. it's spotless and they do charge a 5aed admission which is well spent for all of the facilities. if you look online you can see the endless stretches of sand on both side of the park. the water was clean and clear when we were there and the sand softer than much of dubai.
  3. culture and beauty in sharjah: we did this trip a number of times. we would head up to the museum of islamic civilization for a 30-40 minute visit (if you like science, it's fascinating and my kids also liked it, but it's not interactive), from there, if you have plenty of time stop into the fish market, which is just amazing. head along to the al noor mosque and park there. it's ideal to arrive around an hour or so before sunset so you can see lovely al noor island lit up after dark as well. wander over to al noor island and explore the paths and gardens, sculptures, reading pavilion and ropes course (there is an admission fee). after, walk back over the bridge and head to the right, walking along the bay, to the al majaz waterfront. we liked the playground there and eating at al fanar, the emirati restaurant. lovely on cool nights on the water as they provide blankets. 
4. laser light show and festivities at festival city: i can't remember how many times we did this, but it was a ta friend on the forums who suggested it. it's such a fun mall, and, while we saw all of the fountain shows in dubai this was by far our favorite. especially because every show is different all evening, so you can make a whole night of it. it's stunning with the lasers and the lights and water -- and it's also free. something is always happening at this fun mall -- one festival or another, and they are all great. the holiday inn at festival city is truly a hidden gem. it's lovely, with spacious modern rooms, a fantastic staff, and kids eat free at their excellent healthy restaurant. we kept going back and the kids say it's their #1 place to stay in dubai (against a lof of competition of places which are 5x-7x the price, so there you have it). 
6. getting super posh at versace (not a cheap day): another place we all returned to again and again! if your kids can roll with a more subdued and upscale environment, versace has a dedicated family pool which is gorgeous and warm and excellent food and service. versace china poolside? yes, please. big fluffly towels, great kids menu and a pretty garden and none of the crowds you experience on the palm (but also no beach, but we never missed it). your entrance fee is a little steep but it's 100% redeemable for food and drink and well worth it if you fancy a fancy day with the kiddos. 
dubai (and all of the uae) is a great place for kids. there's so much to do and so much to eat and it's all family friendly. we loved it there!
column8: Our favorite "less highlighted" family activities in Dubai (

column4: mallorca amazing! definitely drive valdemossa, amazing hikes tramuntana mountains. area visit deiá, cala deiá sóller port de sóller (you old tram port, lovely part island) sa collabra must see, walk torrent amazing too. weather good, renting rib exploring calas along north east amazing day out. mallorca amazing wine too, book tour ribas, oldest winery island, lovely options. rose lovely. wine front  definitely try an2 anima negra (and feeling flush), 12 volt, sio. many amazing restaurants palma, definitely time sunset drink es boulard (the museum bar) wall old town. st elm st jordi lovely little towns visit. (i'll stop here, questions shoot message! ) forget ensaimada, crema option fave!
column5: mallorca is amazing! definitely take a drive out to valdemossa, there are some amazing hikes in the tramuntana mountains. and while you're in the area visit deiá, cala deiá sóller and port de sóller (you can get the old tram down to the port, it's such a lovely part of the island) sa collabra is also a must see, and you can walk up the torrent which is amazing too. if the weather is good, renting a rib and exploring the calas along the north east is an amazing day out. mallorca has some amazing wine too, if you can book a tour at ribas, it's the oldest winery on the island, they have a few lovely options. their rose is lovely. on the wine front  definitely try the an2 by anima negra (and the an if you're feeling flush), 12 volt, and sio. there are so many amazing restaurants in palma, but definitely make time for a sunset drink at es boulard (the museum bar) it's up on the wall of the old town. st elm and st jordi are also lovely little towns to visit. (i'll stop here, but if you have any questions shoot me a message! ) and don't forget to have an ensaimada, the crema option is my fave!

column4: @oliviarezac that’s definitely big thing! find room airbnb hostel - cut prices. restaurants, want look smaller portions sides try number things. look public transit budget guides city places freebies museums kind thing. you’re traveling solo - look dates flexibility cheaper pricing (as flights, accommodations, etc)
column5: @oliviarezac that’s definitely a big thing! if you can find a room in an airbnb or hostel - that would cut down prices. when at restaurants, you may want to look at smaller portions and sides so you can try a number of things. look into public transit and budget guides for the city as some places have freebies for museums and that kind of thing. and then since you’re traveling solo - look to dates that have more flexibility for cheaper pricing (as in flights, accommodations, etc)

column5:
ive travelled all over and also was in phoneix one year in early august , phoneix and vegas were scorching hot but did not have the humidity that dubai has , so im just saying maybe take it a tad easily a bit in the day .
we walked with ease the vegas strip at midday and whilst phoenix was hotter it was manageable and we could eat outside with some degree of comfort , although most places did have misters .
no chance of that in dubai, its just to hot.
hotter than than and more uncomfortable would be singapore. ive never found the states that hot at that time ever.
a lot can be achieved in doors and early pm . dubai mall is really lovely in the pm so you could do burj khallifa before it gets dark then move on to the mall /fountains etc. its a huge mall with some highly expensive shops .
mall of the emirates is pretty standard now , but worth a trip if you want to ski at ski dubai.
atlantis and jumeriah beach are nice .
marina more for the late pm with the bars and restaurants - maybe do yellow boats tour but prob best when it is a bit cooler ie late pm.
i would say the theme parks are not as good as the states . ferrari world i thought was a bit to educational but it draws in people for that big ride. never done img i think a lot is indoors as well.

course shirakawago much depends stand hour half bus.

yeah, name hida folk village. people live shirakawago hida folk village museum folk houses.

nada, near kobe, famous producing hard water. region produce dry type.

fushimi , kyoto producing milder type. want taste sake, need breweries izakaya , japanese pub restaurants, do. interested produced, brewery tour worth visiting. except big factories type, sake produced cold season using mold, koji, wrong hot season.
column5:
of course shirakawago is much better but if it depends if you can stand one hour and a half on a bus.

yeah, the name of hida folk village. people live in shirakawago but hida folk village is just a museum of folk houses.

nada, near kobe, is famous for producing hard water. so it is region which produce dry type.

fushimi , kyoto is producing milder type. if you just want to taste sake, you don't need to go to breweries but izakaya , japanese pub restaurants, will do. if you're interested in how they are produced, brewery tour will worth visiting. except the big factories type, sake is produced in the cold season because they are using mold, koji, which will go wrong in hot season.

column4: agree @sammyfd. 5,000 6,000 yen per day enough person's lunch + dinner average restaurant. admission fees attractions depend itinerary. places gardens, museums, shrines temples relatively cheap. 3,000 yen per day per person sufficient. however, looking tokyo disneyland, disneysea, mount fuji, budget. need check individual admission fees calculate budget.
column5: i agree with @sammyfd. 5,000 to 6,000 yen per day would be more than enough for a person's lunch + dinner in an average restaurant. for the admission fees for attractions actually depend on your itinerary. but places such as gardens, museums, shrines and temples are relatively cheap. 3,000 yen per day per person should be sufficient. however, if you are looking at tokyo disneyland, disneysea, mount fuji, that would be another budget. you will need to check the individual admission fees to calculate the budget.

column5:
if you fancy a day trip, have you been to eltham palace or kew? otherwise a walk along the canal from paddington basin to kings cross (take a map because there is a tunnel after little venice) is quite fun.
westminster cathedral is really close to the hamilton theatre (whose name escapes me). it's well worth taking a quick peek (it doesn't get the long queues the abbey does).
i was going to recommend a meal at the vincent rooms (westminster catering college's restaurants), but unfortunately it won't be open until the following week.

column5:
if you go to kenwood in hampstead, you could combine with a visit to highgate cemetery.
lord leighton museum in kensington is lovely if you like pre raphaelite art.
the british library in kings cross.
leeds castle just outside london in kent.
granary square andcoaldrop yard at back of kings cross station has become popular for bars and restaurants. can recommend granary brasserie or dishoom.

column4: see  expense estimates. airfares tend vary lot, check web (airlines online travel agencies). theme parks pricey; much cheaper visit museums, temples, shrines. keep costs down, best strategy cheap "business hotels." food, supermarkets convenience stores cheapest, visitors prefer restaurant meals.
column5: see  for some expense estimates. airfares tend to vary a lot, so you should check those on the web (airlines and online travel agencies). theme parks can be pricey; it's much cheaper to visit museums, temples, and shrines. to keep costs down, your best strategy is to go with cheap "business hotels." for food, supermarkets and convenience stores are cheapest, but most visitors prefer to have some restaurant meals.

column5:
thanks to all for your great posts!
dli_nk - thank you for sharing stunning fall photos.
william512 - also enjoyed your pictures. sakura bloom shots were wonderful, and your flower field pictures inspired me to add the two locations to our trip!
global1715255 - i thought your link to the intro to kabuki was helpful, and will get my husband to watch it before the trip. on your suggestion, i also added an overnight stay at ine fishing village.
hfot2 - my husband and i love easy, scenic bike rides like the kibi plain trail. in okayama, can korakuen gardens and kurashiki visit be combined in one day (mar 29) without overdoing it? if yes, we can then do the bike ride on mar 30, so we can take as much time as we want on the ride. the only other thing we are doing that day is driving to iya valley in late afternoon.
after more research i decided to forego the noto peninsula days, primarily because its not the right time to see the rice fields (flooded in late apr), and i really like the idea of overnighting in ine. i also spent time reading about shikoku. it was hard to decide what to see and what to leave out. i found that the matsuyama spring festival may happen while we are there, so focused on that area and iya valley. here's the latest itinerary version, with more detail added. still need to fill in tokyo, and then work on hotel/travel details.
mar 24 (thu) depart us
mar 26 arrive osaka from us.
mar 26-28 osaka (2 nts)
mar 26 visit kuromon ichiba market (energetic and fun food market), ebisu-bashi bridge (very crowded, iconic picture), nishinomaru garden (cherry blossoms), dotonburi food tour in evening.
mar 27 sumo tournament with guide in edion arena, osaka (this is last day of tournament, expect tickets to be hard to get, advanced tickets on sale beginning feb 6, 2022). go with guide to explain matches, request chair seats, second floor in section a, pref. first row on inner end. (closer box seats are cushions on floor, must sit cross legged for long periods.) typical match schedule runs from 8 am to 6 pm. 2:20 pm - juryo (all prof wrestlers) entrance ceremony, followed by their matches. 3:45 pm – makuuchi (top division wrestlers) entrance ceremony, followed by their matches. 6 pm – competition ends.
after the tournament, have dinner in hozenji yokocho alley – short, narrow, cobbled alleyway with local restaurants next to dotonburi street. while in hozenji yokocho, stop by hozenji temple with famous moss-covered buddha.
mar 28 depart from osaka to okayama. enroute stop at awaji hanasajiki garden (fields of yellow flowers in late march), and himeji castle (beautiful view of castle in spring, do not go inside castle – many stairs and empty).
mar 28-30 okayama (2 nts)
mar 29 okayama - visit korakuen gardens – one of 3 best gardens in japan. visit kurashiki (canal boat ride and/or walk, historical quarter, ½ day).
mar 30 am kibi plain bike trail (flat, scenic trail, allow ½ day or more, bring food and drink for picnic lunch). late pm drive (3 hrs) from okayama to iya valley.
mar 30 – apr 4 shiboku island (5 nts)
mar 30 - apr 1 iya valley (2 nts) iya onsen hotel; vine bridges; old farming villages (ochiai village, togenkyo iya village); oboke-koboke gorges’ cruise (boarding at obokekyo mannaka – 40 min drive from iya valley, 30 min boat ride); statue of peeing boy (shouben kozou).
apr 1 drive from iya valley to matsuyama (2 hrs)
apr 1-4 matsuyama (3 nts) dogo onsen stay.
apr 2 (sat) matsuyama spring festival (held every first weekend in april from fri to sun)
apr 3 (sun) day trip: drive from matsuyama to uichiko village (48 min drive), then ozu village (20 min from uichiko). possible to include drive to shikoku karst?
apr 4 depart from matsuyama to takamatsu (2 hrs) for a visit to ritsurin gardens and lunch of udon noodles. after lunch, drive to kyoto (3 ½ hrs).
apr 4 - 9 kyoto (5 nts):
kinkaku-ji temple (golden pavilion) and gardens just before closing to avoid crowds and for good photography light;
fushimi inari shrine (1000s of red gates, explore bottom area otherwise many, many steps to the top);
kiyomizudera temple - 6-8 am to avoid crowds;
[i know kyoto is famous for its temples, but we are not really temple enthusiasts, so would like to limit temples in kyoto to a few special ones, if possible.]
walk through tenryu-ji temple garden to arashimyama bamboo grove (before 8 am); then walk the higashiyama district early am before it fills with crowds;
walk saga toriimoto preserved street; ishibe alley; ninen-zaka and sannen-zaka streets;
visit heian jingu garden if peak sakura (these cherry trees bloom a little later than others in kyoto, around the tail end of the season, usually mid-april);
visit nishiki market – am, expect it to be very crowded and narrow;
walk along the philosopher's walk (follows canal lined by cherry trees);
geiko-maiko dance performance at kobu kaburenjo theater (obtain ticket well in advance);
kabuki play – try to arrange if one is playing at kyoto minamiza theater while we are in kyoto. dynamic (where actors move more) performances more entertaining than static. schedule not available yet;
private tea ceremony;
visit gion district, 10 course kaiseki meal/foodie tour;
dine in ponto-cho – atmospheric dining area, narrow alley with restaurants;
day trip to imaicho (traditional old town) and umami kyuryo botanical park (beautiful fields of tulips in spring) with stop at nara park to feed deer;
apr 10 depart from kyoto to ine fishing village.
apr 10-11 ine fishing village (1 nt). overnight in boathouse. local fishing private boat tour with guide. bike.
apr 11 depart from ine to kanazawa
apr 11-13 kanazawa (2 nts) - omicho market, kenrokuen garden, visit ainokura gassho comm (and gokayama). check to see if asanogawa enukai festival in kanazawa happens during our visit (traditional dances and other entertainment held on a floating stage).
apr 13 bus to takayama, stopping at shirakawa-go.
apr 13-15 takayama (2 nts)
apr 14-15 (thurs-fri) takayama spring festival (sanno matsuri) – street display of festival floats decorated with sophisticated mechanical dolls (karakuri) that move and dance, karakuri performance at set times during the day, mikoshi procession, evening festival (festival floats are pulled through old town for 2-3 hours, considered festival highlight). festival is very popular, visited by several hundred thousand people. considered to be 1 of 3 most beautiful festivals in japan.
apr 15 before 11 am, depart takayama to matsumoto. visit matsumoto castle – exterior only. the inside has steep, deep steps that may be difficult if knee issues (need about 2 hours for visit). after matsumoto, head to lake kawaguchi-ko.
apr 15-16 lake kawaguchi-ko (1 nt)
apr 16 spend the day at lake: bike ride around lake – takes approx. 3 hours with stops, 20 min boat ride on lake for great views – possibility to see mt. fuji. later in the afternoon, travel to tokyo. if lucky, may be right time for annual spring festival.
apr 16-19 tokyo (3 nts).
apr 17-18 visit tsukiji fish market (go just before 9 am to avoid crowds), need to read alot more about tokyo.
apr 19 fly home

column5:
dli_hk - thank you for your comments. with those in mind, i've changed the apr 1-4 schedule by taking a night from matsuyama and adding a night in takamatsu:
apr 1 drive from iya valley to matsuyama (2 hrs)
apr 1-3 matsuyama (2 nts)
apr 1 (fri) depending on activities and arrival time in matsuyama, may spend some time at spring festival (held every first weekend in april from fri to sun)
apr 2 (sat) if missed festival on apr 1, spend some time enjoying this morning before day tour. guided day trip: uchiko village (48 min drive from matsuyama, visit streets in yokaichi-gokoku areas) and ozu village (20 min from uichiko). uchiko is charming, but so is ozu. ozu has a nice (reconstructed) castle, a small 'old town', a tea house in a tree house and a lighthouse for ghosts. drive to shikoku karst then head back to matsuyama.
apr 4 drive from matsuyama to takamatsu (2 hrs). enroute stop at shiudeyama in mitoyo (beautiful view of 1000 sakura trees overlooking seto inland sea), and at goshiki-dai, “five-colored” plateau in sakaide with nice views of seto-inland sea and the seto-ohashi connecting to okayama.
apr 4-5 takamatsu (i nt)
apr 5 guided tour of ritsurin gardens (a must see beautiful, old style garden – one of best in japan) for a 3-4 hrs or more depending on interest, then have a lunch of udon noodles. there is a nice tea house overlooking the gardens for lunch. after lunch, transit to kyoto (drive 3 hrs or train 2 hrs) with stop at akashi kaikyo national government park (beautiful park with fields of tulips and other spring flowers).
is that better/less rushed?
i've been working on our 2 days in tokyo and have come up with the following:
apr 16-19 tokyo (3 nts)
apr 17 guided tour of tokyo west:
shibuya. experience shibuya district’s neon lights, trendy japanese teens in wild outfits, huge department stores and crowds. shibuya crossing is the “busiest intersection in the world”. a bit touristy, but stop by
hachiko statue erected in memory of dog named hachiko. shibuya itself is the sight to see;
harajuku. walk around harajuku, an internationally renowned fashion district, that is famous for defiantly bold styles and outlandish food trends, its streets acting as fashion runways. 15 min walk from shibuya.
takeshita-dori is harajuku’s most famous street.
shinjuku. shinjuku is known as large entertainment, business and shopping area. in this district you can also find the famous golden gai, a large collection of (really) small bars and restaurants in different alleys.
get a perspective on tokyo’s sheer size from tokyo skytree before sun set;
watch the show at the robot restaurant (temporarily closed). spectacular, high-tech laser displays, multi-coloured lights, flash dances, glittering robots. one of a kind show. reserve tickets in advance. show up about 45 min before show time. have dinner somewhere else.
18 (mon) guided tour of tokyo east:
toyosu market (tuna auction). auction takes place from about 5:30 – 6:30 am. can watch from upper-floor observation deck (opens to visitors at 5 am, arrive early because if crowded may not be able to see much) or special deck on lower floor (request tickets in advance for time slot from 5:55 am to 6:25 am, not a guarantee).
tsukiji fish market. the market opens to the public at 9 am and is extremely crowded. most of market activity ends by 11 am. arrive just before market opens to avoid worst of the crowds.
asakusa. browse around asakusa to uncover tokyo’s best preserved traditional japanese architecture;
tokyo national museum. guided tour of museum highlights for a couple of hrs.
visit imperial palace east garden.
apr 18 fly from tokyo to us
i know that i have short changed tokyo. tokyo comes at the end of a long trip, that is about a week longer than our usual, so i've limited the number of days in tokyo to 2. please let me know how to improve these days.
edited: 3:39 pm, january 07, 2021

column4:
hi, hundreds travellers depart ubud ngurah rai airport need keep mind check time ubud accommodation flight departure time. you’ll understand distance ubud arrival bali.
as you’ve nights ubud perhaps there’s time cooking class shopping ubud brilliant. children pondok pekak library & learning centre ubud activities e.g balinese dance, gamelan, wood carving, fruit carving, balinese offering making, silver jewellery balinese/modern painting offer.
you’re moving lot; unpacking, packing, travelling. you’ll lose time transfers. travelling suitcases? could leave main luggage ubud accommodation hand luggage island trips.
as suggested perhaps could consider sanur last leg. cooking classes available. (i cooking class janet de neefe casa luna/indus fame ubud excellent).
sanur lovely beachfront pathway cafes, restaurants, markets. main road, jalan danau tamblingan, cafes, restaurants, bakeries, supermarket, shops. cycling popular sanur. beach child friendly. enjoy prahu boat ride. approximately half hour airport.
column5:
hi, hundreds of travellers would depart ubud for ngurah rai airport but what you need to keep in mind is check out time from your ubud accommodation and your flight departure time. you’ll understand the distance to ubud on arrival in bali.
as you’ve 6 nights in ubud perhaps there’s time for the cooking class and shopping in ubud is brilliant. your children may like pondok pekak library & learning centre in ubud where activities e.g balinese dance, gamelan, wood carving, fruit carving, balinese offering making, silver jewellery and balinese/modern painting are on offer.
you’re moving around a lot; unpacking, packing, travelling. you’ll lose time with all the transfers. are you travelling with suitcases? you could leave your main luggage with your ubud accommodation and just have hand luggage for your island trips.
as suggested perhaps you could consider sanur for the last leg. there are cooking classes available. (i did my cooking class with janet de neefe of casa luna/indus fame in ubud which was excellent).
sanur has a lovely beachfront pathway with cafes, restaurants, markets. the main road, jalan danau tamblingan, has cafes, restaurants, bakeries, supermarket, shops. cycling is popular in sanur. beach is child friendly. you might enjoy a prahu boat ride. approximately half an hour to airport.

column4:

it important you’re aware ubud locations mentioned post#2. walkable sites ubud central. e.g. puri lukisan museum, antonio blanco museum, ubud palace, ubud market, saraswati temple, monkey forest, camphuan ridge walk. loads cafes, restaurants many cuisine choices prices suit budgets.

column5:
hi, very informative and knowledgeable information from the above ta members. my personal suggestion is to arrange an airport pickup from a ta member’s suggestion for a driver; preferably a driver based in ubud. if you find this driver compatible you would engage him for your day's sightseeing further afield from your base in ubud. and, again personally, i would never self drive in bali.
it is important that you’re aware of ubud locations as mentioned in post#2. there are some walkable sites in ubud central. e.g. puri lukisan museum, antonio blanco museum, ubud palace, ubud market, saraswati temple, monkey forest, camphuan ridge walk. loads of cafes, restaurants with many cuisine choices and prices to suit all budgets.
as you’ve noted there are no taxis/uber allowed in ubud and, for me personally, private drivers are expensive for short trips around ubud. if staying further out check to see if the accommodation offers a complimentary shuttle service to ubud centre and check the schedule.
then you can use the same driver for your transfer to seminyak (with sightseeing on the way if wanted). in seminyak bluebird taxis are plentiful and economical.
we do all our flight bookings, accommodation ourselves; no travel agents. we use booking.com and choose the “free cancellation” option for accommodation. on their site there is a filter, room photos, hotel facilities, reviews, location map. not necessarily to use them but will give you an overview. in seminyak i consider jalan kayu aya (“eat street”) to be “central. plenty of beach clubs in seminyak/canggu. no taxis/uber in canggu. i’m not a fan of airbnb.
bali is currently not open to tourists and you need to be aware of the protocols if and when it may open. perhaps read jacki pomeroy’s covid-19 update on fb. the “rules” are constantly changing and it’s the indonesian government who makes the decisions, not the bali governor.
cheers.

column5:
hi,
first to note to avoid any confusion that the kembali villas you listed in post #3 (perhaps it was an auto link) is not kembali beach bungalows in amed.
kembali villas linked in post #3 are in seminyak.
do you dive or just snorkeling.
pemuteran
check exact location of any property carefully. pemuteran spreads out a long way also inland.
pemuteran is mrs pigs favourite after amed.
we stay at 
you have to walk down the beach a little to enter the sea for snorkeling. main reasons is that their are a lot of sea urchins in the sea along with low lying reefs close to shore. there is a signpost.
entry is more or less in front of the pondok sari.
you will also find the biorock reef restoration project.
the only thing is that pemuteran bay is very sandy (just offshore). at full moon/spring tides/windy/choppy seas the sand can get churned up in the bay. even snorkeling close to shore it can be like snorkeling in a milkshake. literally can’t see your hand in front of your face. biorock not visible.
i’ve been diving well offshore and when in shallower water 10-15m on a sunny day it was like diving in a snowglobe with all the glistening sand.
i use the dive centre on the beach behind the swimming pool/wellness massage centre.

they have 2 dive boats. one rib and one larger fibreglass hull boat.
if only snorkeling you can enquire at the dive centre or others along the beach, about snorkeling trips menjangan.
dive trips often willing to take snorkelers if space. advantage is the boat goes from the beach.
you can arrange snorkeling trips locally but this may involve a road trip in a minibus before picking up a local boat.
out on the main singaraja road you will find a few restaurants geared up for tourists. we particularly like warung tirta sari at tirta sari bungalows opposite suka sari bungalows and warung.
also nearby selini bakery does some nice cakes.

column5:
hello. after many overseas holiday cancellations we have booked a staycation which will include 3 nights at the old bank hotel at the end of july, covering hubbies birthday & our wedding anniversary. i am in the process of planning and am looking for recommendations for;
1. restaurants potentially fine dining options - don’t mind paying the money if the quality & service is good - having said that some of the most memorable meals we’ve had have come from small independent family businesses where recipes are passed down through generations. so the food is the top priority.
2. gastro pubs for leisurely lunches & people watching.
3. nice places to stop for a cuppa & slice of something indulgent after a day on your feet walking.
so far i’ve looked at booking an evening river trip with drinks and a meal at the folly (they do it as a package)
we plan to do a walking tour of the city (recommendations on this welcome) on the morning of our first day & i definitely want to book a guided tour of bodleian library. we plan on visiting the castle & prison. i love architecture, photography (not selfies) jazz & anything vintage.
we have separate day trips outside of these three nights for blenheim palace and a visit to moreton in marsh.
any recommendations or suggestions would be 100% appreciated. thank you.

i'm keen getting value money, i'm quite good it! me, value money necessarily cheap, i'd definitely recommend tower london visitors, i'd balance free enter donations gratefully received attractions - museum london, victoria albert museum, british museum national portrait gallery.
then parks markets explore there's far london museums! i'm personally keen london eye own. prefer river trip north greenwich, ride emirates cable car london dlr. different perspective city.
pub wise, two favourites close together, two ends blackfriars bridge. doggett's south separate restaurant area overlooking river, black friar north end. beautiful historical old pub usually good selection cask ales try. (other choices available!)
column5:
i like to think that i'm not only keen on getting value for money, but i'm also quite good at it! for me, value for money doesn't necessarily mean cheap, so i'd definitely recommend the tower of london for visitors, but i'd balance that out with these all free to enter but donations gratefully received attractions - museum of london, the victoria and albert museum, british museum and national portrait gallery.
then there are the parks and markets to explore as there's far more to london than museums! i'm not personally keen on the london eye but each to their own. i prefer a river trip down to north greenwich, a ride on the emirates cable car and back to london on the dlr. i think these all give a different perspective of the city.
pub wise, two of my favourites are close together, at the two ends of blackfriars bridge. doggett's is at the south with a separate restaurant area overlooking the river, and the black friar is at the north end. that one is a beautiful historical old pub which usually has a very good selection of cask ales to try. (other choices are available!)

column5:
cushendun in northern ireland is clough williams-ellis’s “other” village - built some years before he got started with portmerion and it is also a lovely little place to visit and a good base for the antrim coast.
more of a proper but planned village of course and in a more restrained classical style, mixed with traditional architecture but you can see some of his signature touches in the place.
i remember a good pub/inn and nice walks/river/coast around the place plus a first class campsite.
edited: 4:19 pm, may 28, 2021

column5: i stayed in ramada twice. i visited and walked around la vela but chose the former on second visit because it is more cozy, has a much more beautiful interior garden wise and quieter and more chill. for me la vela is way too modern architecture, huge and impersonal feeling. ramada has a lovely pool with a cool, chill bar and restaurant adjacent. both resorts are next too each other so beach the same. rooms in ramada recenlty remodelled and very lively and modern.

column5:
andaman is definitely a great destination. it is not just about beaches and offers a lot of different things.
lovely, relatively unspoiled, less crowded beaches - if you go to north / middle andaman you may find even less people!
some of the best scuba diving sites in india
the gateway to middle and north andaman - baratang - reaching here is an experience - drive through dense tropical forest - it is also a tribal reserve (you are not allowed to step out of your vehicle) - chance to see jarawa tribal people (hunter,gatherer tribes who dont want to be ‘civilized’ and probably lead a very blissful life and one of the oldest tribes historically)
30 minute boat ride through breathtaking mangroves - something like what you see in nat geo! then trek through forest to see the limestone caves
boat ride through creeks to watch 100s of parrots reach parrot island - their night time home
ross & smith islands that are connected by a sandbar that disappears during high tide
turtle nesting sites (during the nesting season)
the famous radhanagar beach in havelock
watersports in havelock, neil, northbay
coral watching at jollybuoy / redskin
history: cellular jail where british imprisoned and tortured indian freedom fighters, japanese bunkers, remnants of british rule in ross island (this is different from ross & smith), sound and light shows at both
i can go on, but these are some highlights. but beware - facilities are still developing and may not be top notch - may be the reason why it is relatively unspoiled!
hopefully by the time you travel, london - chennai direct flights would have resumed and take a connecting flight from there. (port blair international airport will open soon and you may even have direct flights!)
depending on your interests you can plan. just to give you an idea
1 full day visiting cellular jail,samudrika marine museum, anthropological museum, chatham saw mill (if that interests you) and a sunset watch trip chidiya tapu
1 full day for northbay (sea walking) and ross island
1 full day for jolly buoy - coral viewing and see if you can combine a mount harriet trek in the afternoon
3-4 full nights in havelock enjoying the beaches, scuba, sea walking, snorkelling etc
2-3 nights in neil island
1 day for baratang
3-4 nights for north andaman - ross & smith, 1 full day for saddle peak trek, aam kunj beach etc
there is another great option - if so much of travel is not for you - spend a week in havelock in a resort either on the radhanagar or vijaynagar beaches and about 5 nights in the neil islands and just the night of arrival and night before departure in port blair town!
ps: to reach havelock and neil - you have to take ferries. for baratang, north andaman - you travel by road. self drive cars are not available in andaman, you have to hire a cab with driver

column5:
i went to durham to see the cathedral on tuesday, july 6, and i wanted to share my experience with other would-be travelers.
-book the guided tour in advance. it was sold out for the day i went, and i had been waiting many years to visit the cathedral (romanesque architecture is my absolute favorite). it did not even occur to me that i needed to book many days in advance. i honestly thought i would cry when they kindly said it was sold out*. i texted my children and husband; my husband offered to try to find me a private tour guide immediately, but there was not way that could have worked out. very sweet of him, though.
-tour groups are currently limited to 5 or 6 ppl total. i was confused bc there was at least 1 large school group there on that day; many more than 5-6 ppl. i realize the rules come from the uk govt, not the cathedral. i realize that the cathedral is doing its best to follow what seem to be confusing rules (a big school group = ok, +6 adults in a tour group = not ok). it is what it is--just know them before you go.
-reserve a table in the cafe if you think you might eat there, or eat after 2pm.
*i did not cry, although i may never get to go to durham again (i live in tx), because of the volunteers at the cathedral. i would especially like to highlight hazel, a docent who was so helpful. she was like an angel. she answered my many questions in great detail and was the best of the british--kind, knowledgeable, and with a reserve that comes from a deep well of very good manners. she made me feel i could ask as many questions as i wanted to.
another female docent, tall, thin, with a sporty short haircut, encouraged me to buy a guidebook (which i did) and it was so helpful. many thanks to her.
it was a miserable day--chilly and pouring rain. a chipper younger woman at the entrance pointed out the river path to the bridge, and i'm so glad she did; it was a wonderful (although chilly) walk.
i arrived on a train from london; there is a bus that runs you to the cathedral every 15 minutes or so. many thanks to the women working in the station that day who pointed me in the right direction to catch the bus.
the bus driver was so nice and friendly. such an asset to durham and i'm sorry i did not make note of his name.
i had not eaten all day and, after seeing most of the cathedral, i went down to the cafe on a chance; there was 1 unreserved table at 2:15 (the guided tour started at 2). the women working in the cafe were very helpful. i had the lasagna special (lasagna, bread, and a salad) and a giant (hot and cozy) latte. my lunch was delicious and perfect for the weather.
there was a young, young woman in the gift shop; she was precious and sweet. the shop has a very good book on the architecture of the cathedral which i have been reading.
i wandered around the immediate area before catching the bus back to the train station and back to london. 6 hours on a train; 3 hours in durham.
all of the people i have referenced were at their posts after 12:20 on july 6. they deserve recognition. if there is any way to forward my thanks to them, please let me know.
the cathedral is exceptional and durham, even in the pouring rain, was charming. it was well worth the 3 hours there and 3 hours back on the train.
thank you, durham, for preserving this amazing unesco world heritage site and welcoming people so graciously and kindly. it's the graciousness and kindness i will most remember. and the lasagna. :)

i'm not sure baratang is open now, but it may open around your travel dates. baratang is definitely worth covering not just for the limestone caves, but also the scenic route. you may have to start very early (as early as 3am) and it takes a full day. when you are crossing the jarawa tribal forest reserve, you are not allowed to even get out of the car.
typical itinerary - modify as you need!
day 1: arrive port blair, visit cellular jail, samudrika museum, corbyn cove beach and sound and light show
day 2: baratang or northbay & ross or jollybuoy+
day 3: ferry to havelock, radhanagar beach for sunset
day 4: elephant beach for water sports - snorkeling, sea walking, etc or scuba diving, evening to kalapathar beach
day 5: vijainagar and govind nagar beaches during free time
day 6: ferry to neil, natural beach (guided tour shows lot of marine life), lakshmanpur beach for sunset,
day 7: sitapur beach for sunrise, bharatpur beach for glass bottom boat ride, snorkeling and other water sports, ferry to port blair
day 8: depart

column4:
radhanagar beach famous pristine sands sunset - afternoon - 3pm 5.30 till sunsets enough - felt worth least 4-5 hours (for kid play folks enjoy!) rush!
we skipped scuba seawalking havelock glass boat ride / snorkeling neil (off bharatpur beach) enjoyed both. depends time hand place. scuba - many prefer havelock.
the key deciding factor undersea activity: weather given day high water visibility - suggestion earlier day sunny bright weather devoid clouds, go. wait location - short tight schedule cant again!
if makruzz actual travel time 90 minutes pb - hl. hl-nl nl pb 60+ mins. government ferries much longer. check process complex need report 90-120 minutes earlier depending current regulations - security checks, checking in, verification covid negative report, handing baggage.
collecting baggage arrival 30 mins.- chaotic process.
you book sound light show online - museums guess - checkout available pre-book

water sports booked spot - scuba day earlier preferably
column5:
radhanagar beach is famous for its pristine sands and sunset - an afternoon - say from 3pm to 5.30 pm till the sunsets is enough - though i felt it is worth at least 4-5 hours (for your kid to play and you folks to enjoy!) do not rush!
we skipped scuba and did seawalking in havelock and glass boat ride / snorkeling in neil (off bharatpur beach) and enjoyed both. it depends on the time you have in hand in either place. scuba - many prefer havelock.
the key deciding factor on when to go for undersea activity: the weather on a given day for high under water visibility - my suggestion if an earlier day has sunny bright weather devoid of clouds, go. do not wait for the location - you are on a short tight schedule and you cant do it over again!
if you go by makruzz the actual travel time is about 90 minutes pb - hl. hl-nl and nl to pb should be about 60+ mins. government ferries take much longer. the check in process is more complex now and may need you to report 90-120 minutes earlier depending on the current regulations - security checks, checking in, verification of covid negative report, handing over baggage.
collecting baggage on arrival would take another 30 mins.- it was a chaotic process.
you can book sound and light show online - some museums also i guess - checkout what is available to pre-book

water sports can be booked on the spot - scuba one day earlier preferably

column4:
"my folks senior (beach)"
sorry ... judgement? father nineties enjoyed going beach towns, 'lay beach' kind guy.
beach towns tend breezes help hot summer weather far enjoyable. stroll along beachfront, beats pants stroll car clogged city street. realistically unless require big city amenities (museums, art galleries, big shopping malls), beach communities everything need long stay.
most bigger beach communities substantial expat population along it, home comfort, western stores, foreigner oriented menus such. "local".
but asked hua hin particular, find hua hin modernized western tastes.
column5:
"my folks are too senior for that (beach)"
sorry i have to ask ... did they say that or is that your judgement? my father in his nineties enjoyed going to beach towns, though he wasn't a 'lay on the beach' kind of guy.
beach towns tend to have breezes which help make hot summer weather far more enjoyable. and a stroll along the beachfront, beats the pants off a stroll down a car clogged city street. realistically unless you require big city amenities (museums, art galleries, big shopping malls), beach communities have everything you need for a long stay.
most bigger beach communities here will have a substantial expat population and along with it, a bit of home comfort, western stores, foreigner oriented menus and such. however you can still go "local".
but since you asked about hua hin in particular, i find hua hin to be too modernized and too western for my tastes.

column5:
i notice the replies, some are like-minded, and enjoy knocking around the city's nook & crannies, and 'too long' isn't possible. others, and agree sort of, 3 or 4 nights is more than enough to see the 'iconic' sites, along with a market and or temple or 3.
if living in london, relative, you may or may not like the big mango. i know my first few visits, i hated it, and thought it nothing more than a giant slum. although, i did stay on lower suk, and didn't explore much. if used to squeaky clean western hygiene (appearance / smells (lack of sewer), then you can easily be put off.
now, after so many visits (100+) and still haven't seen it all, as krung thep metro is huge, i love arriving. and after a short week, i love leaving .... 🤣🤣🤣
being there on weekend has its pros & cons, more festive & more things open, but crowded. if you enjoy just knocking around & exploring a city's non touristy side, you'll love it.
but .... since coming from a big city, if so, and wanting beach time, you may want to prioritize that on first visit, as big city feeling can be found at home. especially coming from uk, as any beach, even thai's crappy ones along with warm weather would be a relief, from what i hear & read.🤣
my first thai beach experience was 20+ years ago, phuket, and got me on thinking about retiring in thailand. trip was actually a recon for retirement. 2nd beach holiday was pp, and sealed the idea.
hindsight, and when thailand opens to 'normal' tourism, i think pp would be my priority, as slow starting up again, before it turns back into a tourist ghetto, i think i'd prioritize my first visit after c19 there. save extensive exploration of the big mango for a later visit, as any changes there, will be for the better as they are revamping some areas already, and quite nicely.
about to revisit pp myself, before 2022, as looking lovely without tourist.
good thing not into "museums/galleries" .... they really suck here.
edited: 7:23 pm, january 16, 2021

column4:
"is worth paying 148 floor burj khalifa. move needle experience?"
maybe people. i've dubai numerous times desire there, matter floor. seems least pre-covid people hang block views getting earlier help. i'm like, pay view people going view? course perfect day, see much nothing due weather conditions.
i'm sure "dubai museum/fort" list places go, say, good perspective past current dubai. dirham went times. basically street al ustad. provided complimentary tour arrived time. tours going on, follow small group around. tour guides work dubai government tourists office. worth visit ripleys type setting.
column5:
"is it worth paying to go to the 148 floor in the burj khalifa. does it move the needle on the experience?"
maybe for some people. i've been to dubai numerous times and still have no desire to go up there, no matter what floor. it seems at least pre-covid people would just hang up there and block the views and getting there earlier didn't help. i'm like, why pay for a view and people are going to be all in my view? and of course you have to go on the perfect day, or you'll see much of nothing due to the weather conditions.
i'm not sure if you have the "dubai museum/fort" on your list of places to go, but i can say, it will give you a good perspective of past and current dubai. it was only one dirham when i went both times. it's basically down the street from al ustad. i was provided a complimentary tour when i arrived the one time. if they have any tours going on, you can just follow the small group around. the tour guides work for the dubai government tourists office. that might be more worth than the visit than a ripleys type setting.

column4:
princes street yesterday sunny, unlike day melissa came, doubt people wasn’t busy. struggling understand comparison time square piccadilly circus. don’t see it. aren’t illuminated billboards where.admittedly big departments stores fallen victim covid permanently, looking sad.
the side street balmoral hotel, sir walter scott monument. gardens floral clock, art gallery clear view bank scotland ho mound, 1100 hundred year old castle 600 year old houses beside - heck historic?
i unfair judge city brief day trip london.
if she’s ventured water leith walkway, she’s thought countryside. missed beautiful royal botanic gardens national museum scotland (with excellent exhibitions galloway hoarde).any old town screams history - avoiding it.
each suppose.
column5:
i was on princes street yesterday and it was sunny, unlike the day melissa came, so no doubt more people about but it really wasn’t that busy. i really am struggling to understand the comparison to time square and piccadilly circus. i just don’t see it. there aren’t any illuminated billboards any where.admittedly with 3 of our big departments stores having fallen victim to covid permanently, it is looking a bit sad.
the other side of the street with the balmoral hotel, sir walter scott monument. the gardens and floral clock, the art gallery and the clear view of the bank of scotland ho on the mound, the 1100 hundred year old castle and 600 year old houses beside it - how the heck is this not historic?
i also think it unfair to judge a city on a brief day trip from london.
if she’s ventured on the water of leith walkway, she’s have thought herself in the countryside. she missed the beautiful royal botanic gardens and the national museum of scotland (with some excellent exhibitions on now like the galloway hoarde).any where in the old town screams of our history - there is no avoiding it.
each to their own i suppose.

column4:
june 2019
1. going globe theatre midnight performance audience choice seeing twelfth night got audience applause cheering three options offered us.
2. early evening walk hampstead heath, favorite green space london.
3. drinks outdoors george inn wandering borough market. beautiful weather afternoon made rather crowded tables indicative pre-covid era.
column5:
june 2019
1. going to the globe theatre for a midnight performance where it was audience choice and we didn't know what we would be seeing until twelfth night got the most audience applause and cheering out of the three options offered to us.
2. an early evening walk through hampstead heath, my favorite green space in london.
3. drinks outdoors at the george inn after wandering through borough market. the beautiful weather that afternoon made for rather crowded tables indicative of a pre-covid era.

column4:
september 2020
not long ago, 'tourist' trip london decade.
warm sunny days, london subdued. bridge theatre see two episodes alan bennett's talking heads (a socially distanced production). dinner ivy tower bridge (which busy) leisurely trip tower london, including long chat yeoman wardens; parts closed, relished relative quiet 'being' there. walk monument. several hours exploring museum london. lovely trip.
column5:
september 2020
not that long ago, but my first 'tourist' trip to london in about a decade.
warm sunny days, london subdued. bridge theatre to see two episodes of alan bennett's talking heads (a socially distanced production). dinner at the ivy tower bridge (which was busy) leisurely trip to tower of london, including a long chat with one of the yeoman wardens; although some parts were closed, i relished the relative quiet and just 'being' there. a walk to the monument. several hours exploring the museum of london. lovely trip.

column5:
ok, so this is what i've come up with:
day 1 (thursday 29 april).
- morning ferry from ullaport to stornaway.
- collect hire car at lunchtime.
- visit the standing stones, the blackhouse museum @ arnol, shawbost beach
- drive to kneep. camp in kneep.
day 2 (friday 30 april)
- have a walk around in kneep, then drive to harris.
- (weather permitting) visit the eagle observatory
- take a circular drive round south harris, getting first impressions, and a bite to eat at the butty bus
- find a place to camp, probably luskentyre
day 3 (saturday 1 may)
- ferry over to berneray
- half a day's walking in berneray
- drive to balranald, stopping to walk up a random hill along the way
- camp in balranald
day 4 (sunday 2 may)
- have a walk round balranald
- drive south, doing a little circuit around loch bi and down to daliburgh/south lochoisdale (eating at the co-op), and 2 nights accommodation.
- (weather permitting) a round at askernish golf club
day 5 (monday 3 may)
- visit to eriskay
- possible daytrip to barra
day 6 (tuesday 4 may)
spare day
day 7 (wednesday 5 may)
- head back up to harris
- camp on harris
day 8 (thursday 6 may)
- spend a full day enjoying harris, according to the favourite spots i saw on the way down
- b&b on harris
day 9 (friday 7 may)
- drive back up to stornoway and return the hire car
- visit the knitting muesum
- get the bus back to tarbert for the ferry over to uig

column5:
my boyfriend and i booked flights on a whim... and then started researching and feel like we are totally overwhelmed (we don’t know much about japan but can’t wait to go!)
where do i begin? i got some guidebooks, but there is so much info on them that covers the entire country... i feel like i should nail down the regions were visiting before i start researching because otherwise there’s just too much information.
we are flying into osaka in early november, and out of sapporo in mid/late november (15 days total). we are willing to rent a car or take a train or take take flights between some of the locations… we want to see some cultural sights (temples, etc), eat great food, go hiking, visit an onsen or two, ride bikes around town, etc (not a huge fan of museums but might be willing to do one or two if they are can’t-miss). mostly just love to see (and eat) amazing things.
we love to mix it up too. city/country, luxe hotel/bnb/family-stay/camping, planned guided tours/spur-of-the-moment.
hoping to hit up the south/west when it might still be somewhat warm and see some fall colors, then head north/east (who knows if it will be snowing by then, which could be cool).
we usually like to spend at least three days in a location, so we could probably hit up four regions?
i don’t even know 100% that the trip will happen because of covid - of course it will all depend on what state the world (and japan) is it at the time. i am hopeful though.
would love any ideas of regions to visit, how long to stay there, how to get from one place to another, and any other tips!
thank you so much for your insight.
column8: 15 days in Japan in November. Osaka to Sapporo.

column4:
little cold, snow ice sculptures, festival worth couple days. several winter festivals sapporo area time.

some little challenging sapporo. otaru easiest short walk train station festival sites. asahikawa runs frequent shuttle buses train station festival site.
column5:
it can get a little cold, but if you like snow and ice sculptures, it is a great festival and worth a couple of days. there are also several other winter festivals in the sapporo area around the same time.

some are a little more challenging to get to from sapporo. otaru is the easiest as it is a short walk from the train station to the festival sites. asahikawa runs frequent shuttle buses from the train station to the festival site.
column8: Sapporo Snow Festival? Worth checking out?

column4:
sapporo + snow festival + otaru = roughly days. interested whisky, head yoichi's
nikka distillery. day trip overnight onsen trip, look noboribetsu. depending conditions, able visit parts hell valley. north, addition cranes, abashiri prison offers interesting visit. asahiyama zoo excellent.
it very, cold likelihood. lived michigan years visited snow festival, felt getting hit multiple alberta clippers. walk 15 minutes find place duck inside break.
column5:
sapporo + snow festival + otaru = roughly 3 days. if you are interested in whisky, you can also head to yoichi's
nikka distillery. for a day trip or an overnight onsen trip, look into noboribetsu. depending on conditions, you might be able to visit parts of hell valley. further north, in addition to cranes, abashiri has a prison that offers an interesting visit. asahiyama zoo is excellent.
it will be very, very cold in all likelihood. i lived in michigan for years but when i visited the snow festival, it felt like we were getting hit by multiple alberta clippers. we would walk around for 15 minutes and then have to find a place to duck inside to take a break.

column5:
for my daughter’s graduation trip, we will be spending 2 weeks in japan. the trip will be in may or june of 2023, provided everything gets back to some semblance of normal by then. given the things she wishes to do and things we want to do as a family, here is our itinerary so far. we understand that we may not be able to do everything, but will try to do our most wanted things.
day 1 arrive in tokyo- late afternoon, shibuya crossing and plan to stay at shibuya excel hotel tokyu while in tokyo.
day 2 in tokyo- harley davidson, ghibli museum, tokyo metro government building, robot restaurant
day3 in tokyo- kamishinmeitenso shrine, shiba daijingū shrine, koami-jinja shrine, takagi shrine, sensoji temple, kawaii monster café, nintendo tokyo
day 4 in tokyo- gundam base and statue, teamlab borderless, akihabara
day 5 will take a day trip to nasu hot springs to see sesshoseki, then back to tokyo for the night
day 6 in hakone- stay the night at a traditional ryokan. ryokan hakone ginyu is first on our list because of the private onsen.
day 7 in hakone- gora park, ōwakudani, lake ashi, torii gate and hakone shrine, moto hakone sightseeing cruise hoping to get a good view of mt fuji somewhere. will try to stay at the prince hakone ashinoko
day 8 on to nagoya- atsuta jingu shrine, harley davidson
day 9 from nagoya- hojyuin temple (bảo thọ viện) then on to -kyoto- hozoji temple, international manga museum, samurai kembu show at gion hatanaka. will try to stay at tokyu stay kyoto shinkyogoku-dori, because i believe it to be a good base location.
day 10 in kyoto- fushimi-inari-taisha, shōren-in monzeki temple & teahouse, chion-in temple, kōdaiji temple, kiyomizu-dera temple, ponto-cho alley for dinner
day 11 in kyoto- tea ceremony koto, myoshinji temple, harley davidson, nishiki market
day 12 to tokyo for meiji jingu shrine, yoyogi park, pokémon center mega tokyo
day 13 airport for departure
we will be using shinkansen as much as possible but will need a lot of local trains, buses and subways in each city. we are thinking of adding an extra day in tokyo to fit in everything we wish to do.
a) will the jr rail pass, tokyo metro 72 hour pass be beneficial and save us money? i also see that kyoto offers a similar bus and subway pass.
b) as we wish to do goshuin, how do we know the times and days, shrines and temples are open? any shrine or temple recommendations will be appreciated.
c) on day 7- any better recommendation for hotel with a good view of mt fuji, assuming the weather is cooperating. we wish to stay in the lake ashinoko area?
d) we like collecting harley davidson poker chips, does anyone know if the harley davidson shops in japan sell them? if not we will be settling for shirts.

column5:
i really like the thought of a 10-year old serving as translator and tour guide for his parents! this could be a great opportunity for him! please encourage him to do as much of the trip planning as he can handle!
try to study basic japanese etiquette; there are plenty of youtube videos on this topic.
when to go? check the climate data for japan. the summer is hot and humid. fall and spring are pleasant. try to avoid major japanese holiday periods, which are heavy travel periods for the japanese. i've tried august (way too hot and humid), september (still too humid), october (comfortable), and november (comfortable if you don't mind an occasional chill). there are typhoons in the fall, but i'd rather have a rainy day than a week of high humidity. see  .
where to stay? hotel rooms tend to be small. almost all neighborhoods are safe, so you can go cheap and still have a clean room in a safe area. i stay mostly at the toyoko inn hotel chain, where you get a tiny but clean room and free breakfast. it's a convenience to have a little refrigerator in the room, a microwave in the lobby, and coin-operated laundry machines; toyoko inns have them all. for other hotels, the rakuten travel website is a good start.
the japanese train system has excellent english signage and offers reliable service. you can find train schedules at www.hyperdia.com. consider the national japan rail pass and/or one of the regional rail passes.
if you want to see the katsura imperial villa garden in kyoto, you will need to make a reservation in advance.
consider adding nagasaki to your itinerary; the dejima museum is excellent. for more ideas of places to visit on kyushu, see 
you could also spend a couple of days in hiroshima to see the peace memorial museum, shukkeien garden, fukuromachi elementary school peace museum, and miyajima.

column5:
as khunbill mentioned khao lak covers a long stretch along the highway, probably much more than you remember from long ago.
for most bang niang area is considered to be the main part of town, with lots of eateries, the tsunami museum, the night market and such. nang thong the next beach south is probably number two for easy walking to eateries, shopping, etc.
baan khaolak resort (assuming it is in the same location today) is at the southern end of nang thong beach, so understandable that it was a long walk back then. but today you will find more dining options and such within a short stroll, as khao lak has grown considerably over the years.

column5:
i notice the replies, some are like-minded, and enjoy knocking around the city's nook & crannies, and 'too long' isn't possible. others, and agree sort of, 3 or 4 nights is more than enough to see the 'iconic' sites, along with a market and or temple or 3.
if living in london, relative, you may or may not like the big mango. i know my first few visits, i hated it, and thought it nothing more than a giant slum. although, i did stay on lower suk, and didn't explore much. if used to squeaky clean western hygiene (appearance / smells (lack of sewer), then you can easily be put off.
now, after so many visits (100+) and still haven't seen it all, as krung thep metro is huge, i love arriving. and after a short week, i love leaving .... 🤣🤣🤣
being there on weekend has its pros & cons, more festive & more things open, but crowded. if you enjoy just knocking around & exploring a city's non touristy side, you'll love it.
but .... since coming from a big city, if so, and wanting beach time, you may want to prioritize that on first visit, as big city feeling can be found at home. especially coming from uk, as any beach, even thai's crappy ones along with warm weather would be a relief, from what i hear & read.🤣
my first thai beach experience was 20+ years ago, phuket, and got me on thinking about retiring in thailand. trip was actually a recon for retirement. 2nd beach holiday was pp, and sealed the idea.
hindsight, and when thailand opens to 'normal' tourism, i think pp would be my priority, as slow starting up again, before it turns back into a tourist ghetto, i think i'd prioritize my first visit after c19 there. save extensive exploration of the big mango for a later visit, as any changes there, will be for the better as they are revamping some areas already, and quite nicely.
about to revisit pp myself, before 2022, as looking lovely without tourist.
good thing not into "museums/galleries" .... they really suck here.
edited: 7:23 pm, january 16, 2021

column5:
i think the most important thing to do, particularly when one has limited time is make a plan of what you think, having researched which are your preferences and there are a multitude of “things to do/see” suggestions, as well as asking here on the forums about timings and distances.
plan day by day itineraries so you don’t have to keep doubling back on yourselves. divide singapore into areas and concentrate your daily activities, where possible,
for example, you probably wouldn’t want to go to the zoo and the gardens by the bay on the same day, that’s a lot of walking in one day. so planning is everything.
i’ve often (endlessly indeed lol ) advised people “do less see more”. so planning is everything to maximise your singapore experience.
i know it sounds obvious, but you’ll be amazed how many people think they can do everything because singapore is small, but trust me there is way more to do than you will ever get done, so you can afford to be really selective and have an amazing time in singapore.
as our other friends have said, walking to/from the very excellent mrt can be quite “challenging” especially, if like me, walking is an issue.
taxis, are compared to the u.k, ridiculously inexpensive and super safe. all journeys are metered, which are clearly visible to the passengers, but do not ever allow any taxi driver to “tout” you.
whereas singapore is one of the safest and honest places on the planet, there are always a few rotten eggs in the basket, but very few in singapore thankfully.
just an example in the link of some of singapore’s wonderful attractions.

edited: 8:24 am, march 20, 2021

column5: i feel that geylang serai is never mentioned as a low cost area to visit,it has many reasons to attract non singaporeans especially the variety of foods, malaysian, chinese of all types, cantonese shanghainese,nonya, malay, indian, tamil and baba etc. as a regular visitor since 1970 the area has gotten better each visit. variety, friendliness, and lower costs involved are big draw cards for those who are not on large expense accounts. having lived and worked in singapore in various times, 1956-60 then 1967-1970, 1972-75, plus visits every two or three years, geylang remains in my mind, the most ethnic,realistic and wonderful area after the fabulous zoo and bird parks. the zoo lost its attraction to my wife and i when trevor the white sumatran tiger attacked and killed an idiot who climbed into his area, trevor, sadly the tiger vanished soon after.

column5:

as we have seen over recent years there are many repeat visitors coming for longer stays with a keen interest to explore further. they tend to have done some extra reading and found out about different areas so ask questions about them. i enjoy those questions as it's more my thing.
after a few disappointing experiences in some of the big older popular hotels i quite like more unique hotels, hotels with interesting architecture, or cheaper odd little hotels that other people may avoid, and strangely, some of those little hotels have become favorites.
singapore has something for everyone in so many areas. that's why we all keep returning...

column5:
al maha is smashing - really did like my stay there with a group (we had it exclusively for a couple of nights) they didn't miss a beat for the entire stay. the plunge pools are fantastic for star gazing at night!
i think the desert around qasr al sarah is a completely different ballgame: enormous dunes, sand like flour, and just a magical place. been lucky to stay there and also to camp in liwa just a few massive dunes away. the area is special. couple of hours from abu dhabi (its not a pretty drive) but you can stop at the motor museum if its open which was a nice diversion.
