the kids club and facilities at jumeriah for children are excellent and the wild wadi water park is better for smaller children - the kids club at jumeriah is free and the one at atlantis is chargeable.
the jumeirah property is on the mainland whereas atlantis is at the end of the palm so taxis cost more to get to other areas of the city.
the jumeriah property is closer to mall of the emirates (lots of kids facilities) and dubai mall (even more kids facilities) and the underwater zoo and aquarium at dubai mall knocks lost chambers at atlantis out of the park.

column5:
i don't know what people mean when people talk about business are permanently closed.
a individual may sell or close a business. it happens all the time. i know 80% of businesses close within 12 months of opening in australia. they think they can run a business, turns out they can't. video stores came and went.
the small businesses on the island do not require much capital to set up.
if businesses close. a new business will replace them if there is the demand.
businesses may be closed, the individual who ran that business may have moved on. there will be a new business there if there is a need for the new business.
businesses will only be permanently shut if no tourists come back.
if no tourists come back then the islands will return to the way they were prior to the being converted into tourist zones.
mining towns are the same, the ore runs out, the town's reason for existence ceases. most of the business infrastructure on the islands exists solely to service tourists. it is designed, built and used for one purpose only, to cater for the needs, wants, desires of international tourists.
that is why the islands are suffering so much. no international tourists, no business.
the stuff on the islands is like the stuff in a theme park (island in thailand), no customers, international tourists, then the theme park shuts.
don't worry about the permanent closure of businesses, if the customers come back, the rides will be rebuilt. they will be built to whatever the customer desires.
edited: 11:44 pm, april 14, 2021

day 5:
it got pretty bright 5:30 dark evening east indian time line. served breakfast proceeded towards madhuri lake (sangetsar lake) 7:40 am. reached junction took fork towards madhuri lake. four french toasts started feel sick (could egg yellows?). stopped canteen run sikh regiment. army guys friendly offer travellers biscuits, hot water tea. washroom girls used. effort talk tourists. gurudwara top guru nanak believed meditated. could feel pressure lungs army guy told chance. popped diamox (used altitude sickness) proceeded anyway. road towards madhuri lake downwards soon started feeling better.
we reached madhuri lake 10:45 am. lake stubs trees within it. apparently lake originally forest half century lake formed due earthquake. lake surrounded icy mountains wind chill made place cold temperature low. lake looks good monsoon bright blue color. called madhuri lake madhuri dixit sharukh khan danced song 90s movie – koyla. 90s war, brave soldier called jaswant singh rawat defended indian territory life. assisted locals two women named sela nuranang. sela pass nuranang falls named them.
we snacks army canteen, took pictures left madhuri lake noon. way stopped photo stops frozen lakes. stopped ptso lake made two snowmen. there, hailstones started falling much delight.
after half hour proceeded hotel called arindham wanted monastery. poor guy lunch interrupted it. monastery closer expected reached within mins. went monastery, huge idea do. nevertheless, went in. met local seemed friendly, told works collectors office need assistance tawang, contact him. saw different houses buildings monastery. classes want disturb them. went monastery museum (rs. 20) looked buddhist artifacts. colorful scary masks worn dancers caught eye.
when came museum, classes left courtyard full kids studying lamas. normal kids playing making lot noise. noticed grab packs chips normal kids do.
after left monastery, arindham took mon valley hotel. hotel realized cause sick feeling tummy, could feel churn uncomfortably. soup accompanied momos. monpa people don’t non-veg wednesdays, hotel veg food day. chowmein tasty nevertheless.
sorry detail, got diarrhea meanwhile reached room. started pour heavily (outside hahaha) strong bolts lightening thunder. hotel electricity intermittent starts generator allowed heat water. point lightening struck closeby heater sparked surge. fortunately damaged.

column5:
day 5:
it got pretty bright by 5:30 am and dark by 5 pm in the evening since we were so east of the indian time line. we were served breakfast at 7 am and proceeded towards madhuri lake (sangetsar lake) by 7:40 am. we reached y junction at around 9 am and then took the fork towards madhuri lake. i had four french toasts and started to feel sick (could be the egg yellows?). we stopped at a canteen run by the sikh regiment. the army guys were very friendly and offer all the travellers biscuits, hot water and tea. there is also a washroom which the girls used. they even make an effort to talk to the tourists. there is a gurudwara at the top where guru nanak is believed to have meditated. i could feel a bit of a pressure on my lungs and the army guy told me not to take a chance. i popped up a diamox (used for altitude sickness) and proceeded anyway. the road towards madhuri lake is downwards and i soon started feeling better.
we reached madhuri lake around 10:45 am. the lake has stubs of trees within it. apparently the lake was originally a forest and around half a century back the lake was formed due to an earthquake. the lake was surrounded by icy mountains and the wind chill made the place really cold although the temperature there may not be as low. the lake looks good during the monsoon when it is bright blue in color. it is also called madhuri lake as madhuri dixit and sharukh khan danced here for a song in the 90s movie – koyla. in the 90s war, a brave soldier called jaswant singh rawat defended indian territory with his life. he was assisted by locals two of them were women who were named sela and nuranang. sela pass and nuranang falls were named after them.
we had some snacks in the army canteen, took some pictures and left madhuri lake by noon. on the way we again stopped at some photo stops at frozen lakes. we stopped at ptso lake and made two snowmen. while we were there, hailstones started falling much to our delight.
after half an hour we proceeded back to our hotel and called out to arindham that we wanted to go to the monastery. poor guy was having his lunch and we did not know we interrupted it. the monastery was closer than expected and we reached within 2 mins. when we went into the monastery, it was huge and we had no idea where to go or what to do. nevertheless, we went in. we met a local there who seemed very friendly, and told us he works in the collectors office and should we need any assistance while in tawang, we can contact him. we saw different houses and buildings in the monastery. classes were on and we did not want to disturb any of them. we went to the monastery museum (rs. 20) and looked at all the buddhist artifacts. the colorful yet scary masks worn by dancers caught our eye.
when we came out of the museum, classes had left and the courtyard was full of kids studying to be lamas. they were like normal kids playing around and making a lot of noise. we noticed them grab packs of chips just like normal kids would do.
after we left the monastery, arindham took us to the mon valley hotel. in the hotel i realized the cause of the sick feeling was my tummy, i could feel it churn uncomfortably. i had only the soup that accompanied the momos. monpa people don’t have non-veg on wednesdays, and so the hotel had only veg food that day. the chowmein was tasty nevertheless.
sorry for this detail, but i had got diarrhea meanwhile we reached our room. it started to pour heavily (outside hahaha) with strong bolts of lightening and thunder. our hotel had no electricity and intermittent starts of the generator allowed to heat some water. at one point lightening struck really closeby and our heater sparked with the surge. fortunately it was not damaged.
we ordered food in the room.

column5:
himachal pradesh is my dream destination not only for being home of three shakti peeth or being the playground of gods and goddess (dev bhumi) but for its enchanting nature and beauty. from childhood i am attracted to the mountains of himachal. at very young age have trekked hampta pass, rohtang pass and fell in love. now after 30 years i want to fulfill my dream of going around and absorb as much as himachal pradesh.
must for me: naina devi temple , maa chintpurni temple , shaktipeeth shri bajreshwari devi temple
my interest - i want to cover all the shakti peeths in the area, important and historic temples, gurudwaras, buddhist monastery, mosque and church in this region. i enjoy trekking and nature.
this is my 28 days itinerary to go to himachal pradesh from delhi in june of 2021.
i don't have any idea of any 'off the beaten path' places as i am planning from reading travel books and internet.
i am planning to travel alone in motorcycle or if my wife joins me - then a car.
i want your thought - if it is doable, what places i should stay, what changes i can make to make it a better plan.
let me know what you think :

night stay : chandigarh

for pilgrims:
1. navagraha temples
2. panchabhootha sthalam temples - elements earth - lord shiva temples - water: jambukeswarar temple thiruvanaikovil, sky/space: natarajar temple chidambaram, fire: arunachaleswarar templethiruvannamalai, earth: ekambareshwarar temple, kanchipuram, air: srikalahasti
3. rameswaram temple must visit pilgrims, magnificent meenakshi temple madurai & sriranganathar temple srirangam.

column5:
can you provide some details like where you are traveling from, your mode of transport between temples and the purpose of your temple visit - is it pilgrimage/ are you looking for shiva or vaishnava temples etc would help you get answers for your specific requirements
for the pilgrims:
1. navagraha temples
2. panchabhootha sthalam temples - 5 elements of earth - lord shiva temples - water: jambukeswarar temple thiruvanaikovil, sky/space: natarajar temple at chidambaram, fire: arunachaleswarar templethiruvannamalai, earth: ekambareshwarar temple, kanchipuram, air: srikalahasti
3. rameswaram temple is a must visit for pilgrims, so are the magnificent meenakshi temple at madurai & sriranganathar temple at srirangam.
if your purpose is to enjoy temple architecture - 3 great living chola temples at thanjavur, darasuram & gangai konda chozhapuram.
let me know your specific interest to help you further
edited: 2:51 am, february 17, 2021

spending money....you lot, far need ‘normal’ holiday
being black....such threads lead discussion whether thais racist, xenophobic etc

zoos....thais known animal welfare hot subject

column5:
willybeans, lying on my sun bed here in gran canaria with little to do i will post to help with your research and to explain why you have been labelled a troll and why ‘red flag ‘ comments were made.
you raised many topics that contained certain key words. some of these topics are controversial, even provocative, and they elicit replies that often lead to threads degenerating into online arguments and to threads going off topic and sometimes being closed down.
topics and key words you mention....
spending money....you say you have a lot, far more than you would need for a ‘normal’ holiday
being black....such threads lead to discussion about whether thais are racist, xenophobic etc
hostels....yet your budget is big enough for 5*
zoos....thais are not known for animal welfare and this is a hot subject
floating markets....arguments ensue, are they just tourist traps selling tat?
russian influence....what is that about? you claim to be a first time visitor
2 weeks from usa....leads to discussion about being too short a time for such a long journey
emphasis on being solo, wanting to join up, looking for nightlife...sex tourism?
the fact that you have done limited research
pattaya....results in many trashing the place
if genuine, enjoy your trip. as i posted earlier, don’t fall in love - if you do your us$ 5,000 will not last long at all.

column4:
june equally lovely time visit. plans spend majority time london edinburgh essentially looking city breaks. couple hours rain whilst museum going ruin holiday.
yes wet i've managed cycle friends, sit outside cafe, walks kept indoors month.
either time looking time visit. i'd deciding factor month enables visit / experience something available certain times year.
i.e wanted combine visit chelsea flower show i'd come (yes september off).
column5:
may and june can be an equally lovely time to visit. with your plans to spend the majority of your time in london and edinburgh you are essentially looking at city breaks. if you have a couple of hours rain whilst you are in a museum it's not going to ruin your holiday.
yes it has been wet this may but i've still managed to go out and cycle with friends, sit outside at a cafe, go for walks etc so it's not kept so indoors all month.
either time you are looking at is a great time to visit. i'd have the deciding factor on if one month over another enables you to visit / experience something that is only available at certain times of the year.
i.e if you wanted to combine a visit with chelsea flower show then i'd come in may (yes this it's september but that i think is a one off).
column8: Better Time of Year, First Visit.

column5:
is this a theatre-related job? because that loading bay serves the main theatre suite and its ancillary offices.
for this reason, access from the main/pink zone reception is pretty limited and you would need accompanied by someone with an access card to get in there. probably full ppe too.
there was also an access point from a corridor behind the little cafe at the emergency care centre/a&e (green zone) but its been a while since i last used it and i'd reckon it would be on a card lock or have security on it by now?
edited: 6:13 pm, january 05, 2021

column4:
@toopaz, yes visited landmark couple times re-opened, selladoor took over. quarterdeck café opened toilets closed public. buy something using wc, public before. advertising live stage shows screenings. francis rossi jimmy tarbuck there. theatre re-opened changed hands ian mckellen night, live theatre outside last summer.
it atmosphere before, worse, different.
the landmark used busy lot staff, well ticket kiosks open. local players put oliver christmas. dance groups etc, backroom staff, rooms used groups fairs. stalls displays front foyer, ilfracombe museum. lots going kids front green, bouncy castles like. victorian week costumed actors there; victorian men, jugglers, victorian ladies suffragette re-enactors.
i heard next ilfracombe landmark show sometime 2021, long it'll locked down, something don't.
edited: 4:54 pm, february 03,
column5:
@toopaz, yes we visited the landmark a couple of times when it re-opened, when selladoor took over. the quarterdeck café was opened and the toilets were closed to the public. you had to buy something before using the wc, so it wasn't public as it was before. they were advertising live stage shows and screenings. i think francis rossi and jimmy tarbuck were there. when the theatre re-opened after it changed hands i think ian mckellen was there on the night, and there was some live theatre outside last summer.
it didn't have the same atmosphere as before, not to say it was worse, but it was different.
the landmark used to be very busy with a lot of staff, as well as the ticket kiosks open. local players put on oliver one christmas. there were dance groups etc, backroom staff, and rooms were used for groups and fairs. stalls and displays in the front foyer, such as ilfracombe museum. lots of stuff going on for kids on the front green, bouncy castles and such like. during victorian week all the costumed actors would be there; victorian men, jugglers, victorian ladies and suffragette re-enactors.
i heard the next ilfracombe landmark show is sometime in may 2021, which might suggest how long it'll be locked down, if they know something we don't.

column4:
could hire bikes explore island - super nice day (either island)
jersey couple good castles - elizabeth castle mt oreguil
guernsey castle cornet
occupation museums islands worth visit - islands occupied germans ww2
catch ferry sark guernsey time (no cars hire bike) visit la coupee
victor hugo's house saumarez manor guernsey worth visit.
i worked guernsey months 2002 preference.

column5:
you could hire bikes and explore the island - super on a nice day (either island)
jersey has a couple of good castles - elizabeth castle and mt oreguil
guernsey has castle cornet
occupation museums on both islands are worth a visit - both islands were occupied by the germans during ww2
catch a ferry to sark from guernsey to go back in time (no cars but again you can hire a bike) visit la coupee
victor hugo's house and saumarez manor on guernsey are worth a visit.
i worked on guernsey for 9 months in 2002 so that is my preference.
whichever you decide you will enjoy and remember you get more sunshine on the islands than the rest of the uk

column4:
30 minutes drive thornhill wanlockhead lead mining museum (and tearoom). drumlanrig castle minutes away village (and tearoom) could short drive 15 minutes moniaive visit glenwhisk cafe.
depending upon long mother comfortable sit car, 50 minutes drive via dalveen pass (quite dramatic) biggar could wander cuppa cafes (kirkstyle, aroma, gillespie centre olive tree) spot lunch elphinstone hotel, barony crown. course far dumfries (approx 40 mins drive) lots cafes eating spots e.g. caerlaverock castle outside town (has tearoom), nearby boathouse glencaple cafe overlooking river nith criffel hill.
logan botanic gardens nice (as potting shed cafe) couple hours drive way.
edited: 8:18 am, january 17,
column5:
it's only about 30 minutes drive from thornhill to wanlockhead where there is the lead mining museum (and tearoom). drumlanrig castle is only a few minutes away from the village (and has a tearoom) or you could go a short drive for 15 minutes to moniaive and visit glenwhisk cafe.
depending upon how long your mother is comfortable to sit in the car, it's about 50 minutes drive via the dalveen pass (quite dramatic) to biggar where you could have a wander and a cuppa in one of the cafes (kirkstyle, aroma, the gillespie centre or the olive tree) or a spot of lunch at the elphinstone hotel, the barony or the crown. of course it's not too far to dumfries either (approx 40 mins drive) which has lots of cafes and eating spots e.g. caerlaverock castle outside the town (has a tearoom), or nearby the boathouse at glencaple which is a cafe overlooking the river nith and criffel hill.
logan botanic gardens are very nice (as is the potting shed cafe) but that would be a couple of hours drive each way.
edited: 8:18 am, january 17, 2021

column4:
add suggestions, prepared drive hour direction, kippford (near dalbeattie) kirkcudbright.
kippford nice outlook estuary, coastal drive good tearoom (the ark). drive a710 via dumfries new abbey least way coastal views, return via moniaive countryside outlook.
kirkcudbright picturesque town - castle centre, nice art galleries, harbour, broughton house (nts property) several cafes (the selkirk arms, hotel, nice meals). coast area scenic several good beaches including brighouse bay.
column5:
i would add to the suggestions, if you are prepared to drive for just over an hour in each direction, kippford (near dalbeattie) or kirkcudbright.
kippford has a nice outlook over the estuary, a coastal drive and a good tearoom (the ark). drive the a710 via dumfries and new abbey at least one way for the coastal views, and return via moniaive for a countryside outlook.
kirkcudbright is a picturesque town - it has a castle in the centre, some nice art galleries, a harbour, broughton house (nts property) and several cafes (the selkirk arms, a hotel, also does nice meals). the coast in that area is also scenic and there are several good beaches including brighouse bay.

column5:
welcome,
note at the top of each destination board is a "things to do and see". i have attached a link for your convenience....

just a personal comment. 10 years is alot of time. so depending on what you saw, it may have changed. things like museums can change/offer different exhibits and such.
but from there, you should be able to figure out what to do and see.
when i travel, i usually have 2,3, 4 or 5 things to do in a day, but i do more planning than asking. if things are close together, where i can walk across the street or down a road to see 5 things, i maybe able to do so, but if i have to hop around a city and a large city, it may take more time. then you have the subject. for example, when i was in paris i spent 1/2 + day in there. i had budgeted 1/2 day but i felt and knew i would spend more time.
if all you want to do is to check things off a list, then you can do alot. depending on your interest you may spend more/less time and only you will know this.
if you want to see outdoorsy things like parks, note they will probably be open 24/7. so you can see those on off hours. things like museums will probably have open/close days and so i would focus on those during open hours. and some places may have days they are closed or days that open late.
good luck

column4:
mode travel? cab/own car, best bet trains, limited trains running now. overnight train chennai kumbakonam, local cabs / buses temple visits. thanjavur far kumbakonam. thanjavur, proceed rameswaram bus. madurai return chennai train.
places see: depends interest - pilgrimage type trip, navagraha temples, brahadeeswarar temple multitude temples thanjavur. want enjoy architecture - three living chola temples thanjavur, darasuram & gangaikondacholapuram, require full day. visit danushkodi rameswaram.
3 days short opinion, plan day kumbakonam thanjavur, day rameswaram dhanushkodi third day madurai.
column5:
what will be your mode of travel? if not by cab/own car, the best bet would be to take trains, but there are very limited trains running now. i would suggest an overnight train from chennai to kumbakonam, local cabs / buses for temple visits. thanjavur is not too far from kumbakonam. from thanjavur, proceed to rameswaram by bus. go to madurai from there and return to chennai by train.
places to see: depends on your interest - if it is a pilgrimage type of trip, navagraha temples, brahadeeswarar temple and a multitude of temples in and around thanjavur. if you want to enjoy architecture - three great living chola temples at thanjavur, darasuram & gangaikondacholapuram, but this will require a full day. do visit danushkodi from rameswaram.
3 days is too short in my opinion, so you can plan one day for kumbakonam and thanjavur, one day for rameswaram and dhanushkodi and the third day for madurai.
column8: Need help to plan Chennai to Rameshwaram trip

edited: 6:04 pm, january 10,
column5:
heritage village is not an amusement park but more like a museum/ place of historic interest which gives an insight into traditional working life in the uae prior to becoming an oil rich emirate.
it’s interesting but i don’t think it’s as good as bastakiya and the dubai museum but worth a visit if you’re over this part of dubai.
have you considered yellow boat tour around the palm, you get plenty of photo opportunities otherwise it’s just a case of taking pictures on land on the palm. you’re not going to get an ariel view from the ground ( you might pass over it on the plane)
whilst the palm has some fab hotels you cannot really see it’s shape or design from the ground but yellow boats tour does offer some good photo opportunities
edited: 6:04 pm, january 10, 2021

column4:
want send couple guides could meet museum wander year old inclined keep simple diy.
start museum little wander - relatively cheap keep family entertained hour. walk al fahidi/bastikiya area close (old buildings creek). wander along creek (new called al seef). double textile souk abra station. hop side creek wander spice souk (my fav bit) gold souk. retrace steps side creek hotel.
the abra crossing, maintain, best value dubai aed per person. dusk hear call prayer broadcast mosques.
in june governed heat yo sure water easy.
shout need information.
column5:
if you want i can send you a couple of guides that could meet you at the museum and have a wander with you but with a 4 year old i think i would be inclined to keep it simple and diy.
start at the museum and have a little wander through - its relatively cheap and should keep the family entertained for an hour. then have a walk through al fahidi/bastikiya area which is close (old buildings by the creek). wander along the creek (new bit called al seef). double back through the textile souk to the abra station. hop over to the other side of the creek and wander through the spice souk (my fav bit) to the gold souk. retrace your steps to the other side of the creek to get back to your hotel.
the abra crossing, i maintain, is the best value in dubai at 1 aed per person. it's great at dusk as you hear the call to prayer broadcast from the mosques.
in june you will be governed by the heat and your 4 yo so make sure you have water with you and take it easy.
shout or pm if you need any further information.

column5:
i don't know if you will find what you are looking for here, but the 'antique museum' is a place that you would find interesting (as i note from your other post that you like to shop.) this is a huge place with 'secret' passage ways to other rooms ... rooms and rooms full top to bottom with shelves which in turn are full of stuff. this is the place for souvenirs. not too far from 4 points (in an area known as 'al quoz.')
take a look in the lobby for a plaque regarding the hmsc toronto (and other interesting things.)
i've taken several people there over the years (and one actually purchased a small koran) ... this place has everything; from every knick-knack possible to large wooden sculptures, pashmina, ... and more. you'd love it.

column5:

that might include travels b/w tokyo and hakone yumoto - at the foothills of hakone. the odakyu train serving b/w shinjuku and hakone yumoto direct takes well over 1 hour, though cheaper than by shinkansen.
however, the hakone loop alone takes roughly 4 hours - excluding visits to museums etc. if you arrive at odawara before 11am, there is ample time to complete a full loop.
ps. i used to visit hakone on weekends when staying in tokyo on business trips.

column4:
places kyushu consider:

i recommend nagasaki. atomic bomb museum worthwhile, smaller museum hiroshima. dejima museum excellent. small museum, promoted local tourism office, documents japanese war crimes; see  .
from sendai, could day trips matsushima, hiraizumi, kakunodate. region trying revive tourism 2011 earthquake tsunami, visit appreciated.
column5:
here are some places in kyushu to consider:

i would also recommend nagasaki. the atomic bomb museum is worthwhile, although smaller than the museum in hiroshima. the dejima museum is excellent. there is also a small museum, not promoted by the local tourism office, that documents japanese war crimes; see  .
from sendai, you could make day trips to matsushima, hiraizumi, and kakunodate. the region is trying to revive tourism after the 2011 earthquake and tsunami, so your visit will be appreciated.

column4:
uncomfortable heat humidity. japan august, september, october, november.
from august trip, fond memories highlights kyoto: golden temple, melon cream soda machine south temple, california cola convenience store nearby. heat messed priorities!
my preference mid-october late november. typhoon day two october, days museum shopping days.
the short days fall disadvantage, mitigated wake early (not me!!). stamina sightsee hours day, shorter days matter.
take careful look climate data japan, home city, places visited past. heat humidity issue, trust instincts.
column5:
i am very uncomfortable in heat and humidity. i have been to japan in august, september, october, and november.
from the august trip, i have fond memories of the highlights of kyoto: the golden temple, the melon cream soda from the machine just south of the temple, and the california cola from the convenience store nearby. the heat messed with my priorities!
my preference is for mid-october through late november. there might be a typhoon for a day or two in october, but i can use those days as museum or shopping days.
the short days in the fall are a disadvantage, but that can be mitigated if you can wake up early (not me!!). if you don't have the stamina to sightsee for more than 6 hours a day, the shorter days don't matter.
take a careful look at climate data for japan, for your home city, and for other places you've visited in the past. if you think heat and humidity will be an issue, trust your instincts.
column8: First time to Japan- recommend Mid-May or Mid- October

column4:
#30,
hida folk village vs shirakawa-go - visited both. former akin open air museum whereas locals living latter centuries. could latter, former indeed next best substitute.
in takayama old town, check yatai kaikan yatai used annual takayama festivals exhibited.

there tunnel elbow turns b/w tokyo/shinjuku kawaguchi-ko along chuo expressway - validate google map. unlike bus drivers elsewhere europe, bus drivers japan way cautious seldom abrupt stops unless necessary. besides, japan speed limits much lower - 50km/h national roads less 110km/h expressways. average, hardly steers faster 80km/h.
indeed, train option viable alternative, bus ride comparatively benign. tell it'd bearable. sitting behind bus driver taking window seats suggested sammy good ideas alleviate motion sickness.
train fares b/w shinjuku kawaguchi-ko reserved seats cost jpy4,130. refer route #1 link below.

>>and, course, leaning towards many trains, cost effective jr pass
not really. roughly speaking, 14-day jr pass pays round trip b/w tokyo hiroshima shinkansen (on long distance routes) taken within 14 days. note train fares jr express trains cost much less, jr kaiyu azusa serving jr chuo line. besides, daily commutes city subways covered all. thus, value jr pass drops substantially stationing large cities.
if depart osaka/kix, likely overpay lot buying jr pass, cheap.
edited: 1:35 am, february 04,
column5:
#30,
hida folk village vs shirakawa-go - have visited both. the former is more akin to an open air museum whereas locals have been living in latter for centuries. for those who could not make it to the latter, the former is indeed the next best substitute.
in takayama old town, also check out the yatai kaikan where yatai used in the annual takayama festivals are exhibited.

there is no tunnel nor elbow turns b/w tokyo/shinjuku and kawaguchi-ko along the chuo expressway - validate on google map. unlike bus drivers elsewhere in europe, most bus drivers in japan are way more cautious and seldom make abrupt stops unless it's necessary. besides, in japan the speed limits are much lower - 50km/h on national roads and less than 110km/h on expressways. on average, it hardly steers faster than 80km/h.
indeed, the train option is a viable alternative, though bus ride is comparatively benign. only you can tell if it'd be bearable. sitting behind the bus driver and taking window seats as suggested by sammy are some good ideas to alleviate motion sickness.
train fares b/w shinjuku and kawaguchi-ko for reserved seats cost jpy4,130. refer to route #1 in the link below.

>>and, of course, with my leaning towards so many trains, it might make it more cost effective for us to get the jr pass
not really. roughly speaking, the 14-day jr pass pays off if a round trip b/w tokyo and hiroshima by shinkansen (on long distance routes) is taken within 14 days. note that train fares of jr express trains cost much less, such as jr kaiyu or azusa serving the jr chuo line. besides, daily commutes on city subways are not covered at all. thus, the value of jr pass drops substantially while stationing in large cities.
if you depart from osaka/kix, then it's very likely you'd overpay a lot by buying jr pass, which is not cheap.
edited: 1:35 am, february 04, 2021

column5:
hello!
we are in the early stages of planning a trip for our family of four in may 2022. we are a couple in our 40’s with two children age 19 and 14. we are budget travelers, and typically do airbnb when traveling to europe. our interests are: anime and pop-culture, amusement parks, architecture, great inexpensive food, stunning natural sights, light hiking, art, some of the must-see temples but not a temple every day, unique cultural experiences.
i would appreciate your input on the following itinerary:
day 1 - fly out of the us
day 2 - arrive in japan and get settled
day 3 - 7 - tokyo
(priorities in tokyo are: harajuku and akihabara for anime and pop culture, ghibli museum, disneysea or skycircus or both, teambordeless lab, imperial palace and 1 temple/shrine, hedgehog or owl café, unique pop culture activity suggestions welcome)
day 8 - travel to jigokudani monkey park, stay in matsumoto or kamikochi area (we are thinking about renting a car for this leg of the trip in the more rural areas)

column5:
tokyo: i told our guide that i am disabled and have a mobility impairment. i cannot walk more than very short distances and very slowly. he seemed to forget this and walked way ahead of our group (of four people) and seemed unaware that i was struggling to keep up. to his credit, he took us to the edo-tokyo museum and it was very interesting. with my mobility impairment, i could handle it very well and sit down whenever needed.
hakodate: our guide was a grandmother and just the nicest, kindest person you would ever meet. we wish she lived next door to us in america. walking was kept to a minimum, thankfully.

'it seems policy brought show something done, rather try set effective way stop variant covid cases getting country.' agree, done canada.
the variants present uk, canada, states, plenty countries. trying keep contained reasonable plan, making travellers culprits spreading variants theatre rather based facts.
if quarantine continues canada uk month i'd see numbers cases variants time see measures desired effect, doubt numbers drop zero measures taken.
vaccination canada wretchedly slow promises doses delivered week. provinces need needles arms quickly possible encourage basics continue (with request reduce domestic travel much possible) rather focus international travellers bigger problem.
column5:
'it seems to me that this policy has just been brought in to show that something is being done, rather than to try to set up an effective way to stop variant covid cases getting in to the country.' i agree, and the same is being done in canada.
the variants are present in the uk, canada, the states, and plenty of other countries. trying to keep them contained is a reasonable plan, but making travellers the culprits for spreading variants may be theatre rather than based on facts.
if quarantine continues in canada and the uk for a month i'd like to see the numbers for cases and variants at that time to see if these measures will have had the desired effect, as i doubt numbers will drop to zero with the measures taken.
vaccination in canada has been wretchedly slow with promises of more doses to be delivered this week. the provinces need to get needles in arms as quickly as possible and encourage the basics to continue (with the request to reduce domestic travel as much as possible) rather than focus on the very few international travellers as a bigger problem.

column5:
hi, the main sites can be done easily within a day, or even half a day. a whole day would allow a nice slow amble, time to check out the shops, grab a meal, coffee etc. neither the castle nor the cathedral are particularly large and can be seen in about 30 mins each. the guildhall museum, eastgate house and six poor travellers house are the other historic places of interest along the high street, away from the high street there’s not a lot to see apart from restoration house which has very limited opening days.
to make an overnight of it, you could combine with chatham historic dockyard which is just two miles away.

column4:
geffrye museum refurbishment new name  prior certainly worth visit. small greenspace museum kingsland road favourite spots escape busyness london - despite adjacent main road peaceful area walk sit think. garden rear museum lush high summer well, good nick next month.
i change made access museum hoxton overground station, bus liverpool street 149 - alight stop hoxton station stop far side falkirk street nearer museum entrance.
column5:
the geffrye museum has had a refurbishment and new name  but prior to that was certainly worth a visit. the small greenspace between the museum and the kingsland road has been one of my favourite spots to escape the busyness of london - despite being adjacent to the main road it's always been a peaceful area to walk or sit and think. the garden at the rear of the museum is lush in high summer as well, and should still be in good nick next month.
i think there has been a change made to access to the museum from hoxton overground station, but if you'd like to take the bus from liverpool street the 149 will take you there - don't alight at the stop for hoxton station but use the stop on the far side of falkirk street as it's nearer the museum entrance.

column5:
i've been to london (mostly) as a solo female traveler over 70 times! (mr. jtwiz has joined me 5 of those trips.) so i'm always on the lookout for something new to do or re-visit some place that has a special exhibit for example.
i agree with visting the wallace collection - definitely take the free guided tour. you learn so much from it. my last trip there was to see a fantastic exhibit of manolo blahnik shoes that were interspersed with the art collection. that's the kind of exhibit i look for.
i notice you didn't mention the v&a. that is by far my favorite museum in london. i've gone there countless times. i see they currently have an exhibition of hand bags, it looks great.
the churchill war rooms are indeed worth a trip. absolutely fascinating tour. i also love greenwich, beside visiting the observatory, the maritime museum is also interesting. and i always enjoy perusing the small street market in greenwich as well. definitely take a boat at least one way. always fun to see london from the water.
do you like gardens? the royal botanic gardens at kew are fantastic and easy to get to via tube. fyi. my last trip there was to see the chihuly exhibit. wow, that was a great day out.
other easy day trips include windsor, hampton court palace, st. albans.
edited: 10:17 am, august 26, 2021

column5:
greenwich has been mentioned a few times and has so much it could fill your day ...
definitely a boat trip one way, but i like to go out on the dlr to island gardens on the north side of the thames, from where you get a great view of the naval college across the river, then walk under the thames through the victorian pedestrian tunnel.
the first time i went through canary wharf (having never seen the skyscpaers of the states) i felt like i was in batman' gotham city!
you can do a variation by getting off the dlr a couple of stops earlier at mudchure, visit the city farm for the surreal sight of sheep against the background of skyscrapers (!) then walk down through the isle of dogs to island gardens.
over in greenwich itself i love the maritime museum, so much about exploring the world over the centuries (free, so if less your thing you don't need to spend much time, but there is also a great shop) . there's also the observatory and the meridian line, greenwich park, the cutty sark, the market ( not sure which days). i've now discovered that the queen's house sounds really interesting, and regret not visiting. greenwich was one of the homes of the tudor royals, and i believe henry viii was baptised at the church (st. afage's???). interesting to think of the baptising of the baby that would go on to sever the church from rome .....!
all that's a very full day, but you could be selective ....
edited: 2:02 pm, august 30, 2021

column5:
>>after watching doc martin cornwall is definitely on the list !<<
ok so if crowds are why you want to avoid big cities you then need to think wider than cities. port isaac where doc martin is filmed can get horribly busy. in april the crowding in padstow when we went was bad enough we skipped through to a couple of things we really wanted but left to go elsewhere faster than we normally would.
there are popular places that get very crowded (durdle door on the south coast for example). popular attractions that are gated, tintagel castle leaps to mind, didnt suffer the crowding problems earlier this year as they controlled numbers well. however open access places - more of a problem. that will be true throughout the uk and the solutions will equally vary.
oh and i highlighted a few places that i like - part of my point was that despite being good there are a lot more that you can and will enjoy that you need to look at rather than simply follow my list. where your interests and mine diverge, so can our enjoyment of some places. it takes a lot to get me into an art gallery or studio for example (although maurice bishop is one exception that i make routinely)

column4:
lot see edinburgh castle.
crown square top castle houses hall, royal apartments, mary queen scots birthing room, national war memorial.
there display honours scotland, crown jewels, stone destiny, upon scottish uk monarchs crowned (before moving new perth city hall 2024).
as beseiged castle uk, army barracks, emphasis military history, national museum scotland's national war museum located castle, along regimental museums royal scots royal scots dragoon guards, plus prisons napoleonic war.
finally, castle site o'clock gun, fired time signal six days week, sundays.
column5:
there is a lot to see at edinburgh castle.
crown square at the top of the castle houses the great hall, the royal apartments, with mary queen of scots birthing room, and the national war memorial.
there is also the display of the honours of scotland, our crown jewels, and the stone of destiny, upon which all scottish and now uk monarchs have been crowned (before moving to the new perth city hall in 2024).
as the most beseiged castle in the uk, and as still an army barracks, there is an emphasis on military history, with the national museum of scotland's national war museum located in the castle, along with the regimental museums of the royal scots and royal scots dragoon guards, plus the prisons from the napoleonic war.
finally, the castle is the site of the one o'clock gun, that is fired as a time signal on six days a week, not sundays.

column4:
tour sense unlimited budget, want japanese economy boost, terrified foreign country, want travel remote areas, need special assistance, busy uninterested plan trip.
all typical trip destinations easily reached public transportation, mostly trains subways. trains subways excellent english signage, many american cities. buses little difficult, need much drivers quite helpful foreign tourists. plan trip yourself, decide much time spend location, based interests. spend full day tokyo national museum 10 minutes gift shop! choose hotels fit budget. pay services tour escort tour bus. money save taking tour, could extend trip 2, 3, weeks, time enjoy japan. deal risk tour include annoying person chatters endlessly never stops complaining.
(keep mind people post answers forum travel independently, detect hint bias.)
column5:
a tour would make sense if you have an unlimited budget, want to give the japanese economy a boost, are terrified of being in a foreign country, want to travel only to remote areas, need special assistance, or are too busy or too uninterested to plan your trip.
all typical first trip destinations can be easily reached by public transportation, mostly trains and subways. trains and subways have excellent english signage, actually better than many american cities. buses are a little bit more difficult, but you won't need them very much and the drivers are quite helpful to foreign tourists. if you plan your trip yourself, you can decide how much time to spend at each location, based on your interests. you can spend a full day at the tokyo national museum or just 10 minutes at their gift shop! you can choose hotels that fit your budget. you won't have to pay for the services of a tour escort or tour bus. with the money you save by not taking a tour, you could extend your trip to 2, 3, or maybe even 4 weeks, which will give you more time to enjoy japan. and you won't have to deal with the risk that the tour will include an annoying person who chatters endlessly and never stops complaining.
(keep in mind that most of the people who post answers on this forum travel independently, so you might detect a hint of bias.)

column4: obviously can't guarantee see given day - famous clouds obscuring view. lucky hakone loop gloriously clear. however, loop trains, cable cars, black eggs, pirate ships etc. public transport. loads info net youtube. hakone good museums/galleries course famous onsen. book private ones hotels fancy public ones (also onsen theme park thing.... www.yunessun.com).
column5: obviously you can't guarantee you can see it on any given day - famous for clouds obscuring view. i was lucky did the hakone loop and it was gloriously clear. however, even if it wasn't the loop itself is great with the trains, cable cars, black eggs, pirate ships etc. all public transport. loads of info in the net and youtube. also hakone has good museums/galleries and of course if famous for onsen. can book private ones or hotels with their own if you don't fancy public ones (also a onsen theme park thing.... www.yunessun.com).

column5:
hello! we jumped on one of the cheap tokyo flight deals for november with the expectation that we will likely have to push the trip further out... but in the meantime, i love researching and planning trips, and here i am digging through tripadvisor again!
we did an amazing 2 weeks in japan in november 2019 and covered all of the major first-timer places: tokyo, kamakura/enoshima, kyoto, nara, osaka, himeji, hiroshima/miyajima, fukuoka (sumo tournament/nanzoin buddha). disneysea.
now i'm looking for advice on what to do for a second trip! we love doing a bit of everything - covering the most famous stuff, pretty temples/gardens (especially if we are there for fall leaves) again, easy hikes, eating, and just wandering. my husband does japanese calligraphy as a hobby, so we're also looking for museums/classes/shops for his interests.
we are planning to do hakone/mt. fuji area and a few days around kyoto/osaka because there is so much to see and do there (i really want to do the aquarium!). and in my research, i've recently discovered the "diamond route" term for fukushima, ibaraki, and tochigi prefectures. since nikko is definitely a place i want to go this time, i was wondering if the other locations are worth spending 3-4 days exploring, something like: tokyo > mito > koriyama > urabandai > aizu-wakamatsu > ouchijuku > nikko > utsunomiya > tokyo?
we would do this ourselves on trains/buses, not through a tour company, but here are example itineraries to illustrate what i'm thinking: 
so any other advice for our second trip itinerary?
days 1-2 tokyo
3-7 diamond route? or just a nikko day trip and then go somewhere else?
8-11 kyoto/osaka - other day trips besides nara to do?
12-14 hakone/mt. fuji
15 tokyo and return flight
thanks for your help!

column5:
>>most of the travel agencies keep telling me that is out of the way and that i should go to hakone instead.
have they visited both hakone and nikko before ?
although nikko is not along the way b/w tokyo and kyoto, it's easily accessible as day trip from tokyo due to efficient and reliable public transports. have visited it 5 times with 2 overnight stays from tokyo.
hakone - while there is an old tokaido trail and checkpoint, it's more famous for sightseeing, onsens spread out in the mountains, apart from several museums.

note that hiking trails around hakone owakudani might be temporarily closed due to elevated volcanic activities.

column5:
i spent 2.5 days/3 nights in naha, i am not a beach person so did not go north to the resorts, i visited the ww2 japanese underground naval hq, city/prefecture museum, the himeyuri site and the peace memorial park, shuri castle burned down a few months before my arrival but i still went up and walked around the grounds. from naha i went to taipei. yoichi is easy to get to by train from sapporo, you will need to change trains in otaru, go to yoichi in the morning and return to otaru in the afternoon to see the festival and leave in the evening after seeing the sights after dark, the bank of japan museum is worth a visit. the distillery is a short walk from the train station, check out the shop in the station as it had a few nikka whiskies that the distillery shop was out of. the distillery has a tasting room where you can buy by the glass plus there is also a separate building with free tastings of three decent sized samples of apple wine, yoichi whiskey and another whiskey i think it was the super rare. check the train schedules on hyperdia.

column5:
while ginyu hakone is a nice onsen ryokan - no experience, check out yunessun in hakone kowakien where you may soak in swimming suits (together as a family) or reserve private baths in mori-no-yu area (not cheap).

for most visitors, an overnight stay in hakone would suffice after a day visit along the hakone loop, excluding museum visits.
consider the odakyu hakone freepass which payoff after completing the loop once. in your case, buy it after arriving at odawara station by tokaido shinkansen.

in kyoto, take city subways and commuter trains including hankyu, keihan as much as possible to avoid traffic jams. city buses are slow and usually quite full along popular routes. with 3 adults or more, just take a taxi to spots not closely served by public transports.
edited: 2:22 am, june 19, 2021

column5:
i visited japan about 40 times staying in 4 star hotels with all expenses paid, before making a number of visits paying my own way. the difference was considerable! instead of paying £6 for a cup of tea l was trying to get a meal for that. the key is to eat a mixture of american fast food and cheap japanese which can be found by finding places that are popular with young people. it helps if you like rice as that is the main source of calories. i don't much and once when i was taken to one of the best restaurants in kyoto at the height of what is known as the bubble economy, where the bill was close to £1,000 a head, l got a hamburger at wendy's on the way back to the hotel! buying in supermarkets one of the problems is recognising what you are getting. i bought what were obviously chocolates only to find they were dried fish.
i don't much like business hotels. the only one l stayed in had a tiny window too high up to see out of and by stretching my arms l could touch both sides of the room. i like the b hotels, which mainly have a young clientel and l have stayed in the one in akasaka a number of times. it also has the advantage of being close to the new otani, where l used to stay, so l can go for a stroll in the famous garden and buy an overpriced cake and a coffee. (japanese men only buy cake in secret).
for the japanese experience it is worth having a night in a cheaper ryokan, which will still not be cheap, but l never feel comfortable as no one speaks english and l don't have a clue what is going on. expensive ones have english speaking staff but they really are expensive.
the japanese are very envious of people who can buy a rail pass which allows you, should you choose, to take a thousand or more pounds of travel for a couple of hundred. i really love travelling on the shinkansen, which is fast, civilised, spacious and, by high speed rail standards, very quiet. it is an experience to see the japanese collect all their rubbish and queue to put it in the appropriate bins at the end of the journey leaving the train immaculately clean. (you will see them looking disapprovingly at foreign tourists who don't do the same).
to experience japanese standards of service buy your rail passes from jtb in london and, if you can afford the extra fare, fly with jal or anna.
we were brought up in northern ireland which we visit every year and l find costs as a visitor not significantly different to those in japan. something that is different is that it is much cheaper to visit japanese tourist sites such as shrines and temples.
at any rate outside tokyo it is worth considering an occasional stay in a four star hotel as room rates can be very reasonable. the osaka new otani, an excellent hotel, is no more expensive than the radisson at shaw's bridge. just don't eat in the hotel or buy one of the paintings in the art gallery. when l once asked the price of one the sales person didn't have enough zeros on the calculator to show me.
at least with your girlfriend you won't be tempted to have a look at any of the dodgier clubs in shinjuku. an innocent university lecturer l knew paid £10 to get into one and £500 to get out again.

column5:
thanks for all your comments. i learn as much as i can in preparation for a september 2021 trip to japan that may not even happen because of the coronavirus restrictions that will be in place when the calendar turns to autumn. i stay tuned and hope for the best while i do my research.
for those of you who want to know a fuller description of how this journey takes shape, read on.
i will travel with my wife who may or may not need a wheelchair to move about. if we were to travel right now she definitely would because long walking would set off pains in her leg, shoulder and arm. she's still mobile enough to climb a flight of stairs, hop on and off an escalator, or wander around a beautiful garden or temple if necessary. we'd rather take an elevator to change elevation, of course. we are both in our 70s, and the blush of youth has fled our bodies, but i'm fit enough to wrestle a wheelchair up stairs or in and out of an uncrowded subway train.
i've already done some web research, and the stories and information i find there suggest that wheelchair travel in japan is not all that difficult. as i wrote earlier, my immediate concern is about getting from place to place not in making the visit to a sight. i still expect her to use the wheelchair for museum visits and for "strolling" around a street lined with shops.
we're used a wheelchair before at museums and airports and have found that they serve us well. however, those environments are very wheel-friendly. on the street i expect to encounter rough or uneven pavement, curbs, and crowds.
i'd like to focus this thread on crowds, specifically how would a crowd crossing a busy intersection deal with a wheelchair? robert w and global report that they rarely see wheelchairs in public, would japanese automatically give way to an approaching wheelchair, or would the wheelchair introduce a bit of chaos to an otherwise orderly system?
also, my original posting asked about crowds on the subway in the evening. if we go back onto the subway in the evening, what will be the best hours to travel?
by the way global, there's a part of me that enjoys confronting the difficulties of traveling in a foreign place; negotiating the tokyo subway should prove enlightening.

column5:
shanghai disney is in shanghai, while great wall is in beijing. unless you get a chinese tourist visa, you can only make use of the visa free transit period at shanghai and beijing. you can book your ticket as yyz - sha - tyo - pek - yyz. however, you will have only 6 days in each transit point, assume you are using a canadian passport.
i would skip china and put all the time in japan indeed. with the disneyland and disneysea in tokyo, i don't think you still want to the shanghai one anymore. on the other hand, what to add in japan depends on your interest. if you love world heritage in architecture, japan does offer lots of world heritage as well.

column4:
going onsen, public hot bath, japanese experience. country. visited two, matsuyama, matsumoto. dogo onsen matsuyama nice old fashioned styled building, onsen went modern building. getting used naked complete strangers, genders separated.
i enjoyed visiting sumo wrestling stadium tokyo. wrestling, small museum. real highlight plenty actual sumo wrestlers stadium area. easy recognise big, plus wearing traditional costumes.
column5:
going to an onsen, that is a public hot bath, is a very japanese experience. they are all over the country. i have visited two, one in matsuyama, and one in matsumoto. dogo onsen in matsuyama is especially nice because it is in an old fashioned styled building, the other onsen i went to is in a modern building. it does take a bit of getting used to being naked with complete strangers, but genders are separated.
i also enjoyed visiting the sumo wrestling stadium in tokyo. there was no wrestling, but it does have a small museum. but the real highlight was that there were plenty of actual sumo wrestlers in and around the stadium area. they were easy to recognise because they are so big, plus they were wearing traditional costumes.

edited: 5:44 am, june 11,
column5:
with about 9 days in japan, i recommend allocating 4 days in tokyo and 5 days in kyoto/osaka in your short visit.
of course it's your call to spend as many days as you want on theme parks, note that those do not offer authentic aspects of that country. while disneyland is the same in every location except for the language - (i've been to all 4 of them), consider dropping it but allocating to tokyo or kyoto where there are plenty of local spots worth visiting.
tokyo - apart from the usual spots in asakusa, ginza, shinjuku, shibuya etc,, spend a few hours in teamlabs in odaiba - plenty of videos on youtube.
hakone - visit it for a few hours while travelling enroute to kyoto. depart early from tokyo and complete the whole loop once by taking the various transports by odakyu. manage your expectations that mt fuji might not be seen in summer as mentioned. on clear days, it can be viewed along the ropeway and partially from lake ashi.
do check out japan-guide.com for major attractions.
happy planning.

column4:
vote hakone, favorite place world. stay overnight can, makes easier hot springs (for parents, kids). kids love outdoor activities.
there‘s half-day nature tour includes boat, train, cable car, etc. transit focus sounded silly, tour nice! (we didn’t kids time.) kids fun different types transport. (i “tour” it’s public transit, organized tour.)
the hakone open-air museum outdoor sculpture park (and indoor picasso section) nice way see art kids getting bored. there’s (warm?) foot bath on-site well.
we loved hotel manatei (aka club manatee) ryokan-like experience. got room private bath (+$100 usd) = private onsen overlooking trees babbling brook. worth every penny. hotel onsen rooms guests reserve, you’ll tied schedule subject availability. much easier it’s room, sneak whenever kids fall asleep, turns parent room vs going downstairs soak. (i don’t kids soak hot water, way.)
technically hotel manatei isn’t ryokan. don’t exactly makes ryokan. wanted small/local place, gave yukata (pajamas wear premises) kaiseki dinner, manatei had. dinner excellent! dinner served restaurant instead in-room, beds western (not futon tatami mats), it’s ryokan?
column5:
another vote for hakone, maybe my favorite place in the world. stay overnight if you can, which makes it easier to do hot springs (for the parents, not kids). kids will love the outdoor activities.
there‘s a half-day nature tour that includes a boat, train, cable car, etc. the transit focus sounded silly, but the tour was really nice! (we didn’t even have kids at the time.) kids will have fun with the different types of transport. (i say “tour” but actually it’s all public transit, so not like an organized tour.)
the hakone open-air museum has an outdoor sculpture park (and indoor picasso section) which is a nice way to see art without the kids getting too bored. there’s a (warm?) foot bath on-site as well.
we loved hotel manatei (aka club manatee) for a ryokan-like experience. we got a room with a private bath (+$100 usd) = private onsen overlooking trees and a babbling brook. worth every penny. the hotel also has onsen rooms that guests can reserve, but you’ll be tied to a schedule and subject to availability. much easier if it’s in your room, you can sneak in whenever the kids fall asleep, and not have to take turns with one parent in the room vs the other going downstairs to soak. (i don’t think kids like to soak in the very hot water, by the way.)
technically hotel manatei isn’t a ryokan. i don’t know exactly what makes a ryokan. for us we wanted a small/local place, that gave us yukata (pajamas to wear on the premises) and kaiseki dinner, which manatei had. and the dinner was excellent! dinner was served in the restaurant instead of in-room, and the beds were western (not futon on tatami mats), which may be why it’s not a ryokan?

column5:
ten days is not too long. you list 10 nights in the three cities, but if you are travelling from and back to hcmc on days and 10, isn't that only 9 nights?
i suggest flying to hue and back from danang (or vice versa) to have one less 'moving day', checking in and out of accommodation - unless you already plan to go by rail one way and road the other between danang and hue.
in hue, the imperial citadel is worth a visit and with no large international tour groups around you shouldn't find it crowded. cycling is easy around the citadel and between there and thien mu pagoda in the leafy streets and garden houses of kim long. it is cooler there than the citadel and central area of the city. you can find good local food and cafes in both areas.
outside the city, distances make a motorcycle or car a better choice. it will also be very very hot in july.
some suggestions:
huyen tran princess temple. i've never seen many there. past the top building to the left are stone steps to the peace bell and good views worth the climb.
dong khanh and gia long tombs receive fewer visitors than the three tombs on most itineraries. they are all worth a visit but two or three is enough for most on one day.
thanh toan bridge, which has recently undergone restoration work, is 7km out of town through vast rice paddies. it is right beside a small market and a small rice growing museum is nearby. a relaxing place.
thuan an beach will be busy before 9 am and after 4pm and quiet in between. along the way from the city i like to stop at cho no, a riverside market. futher on you could detour a little to chuon lagoon. if you want to venture south from there - over 25km more - you'll find an bang aka city of ghosts with its hundreds of extravagant ornate tombs. there is a shorter route back via phu bai.
if you aren't renting a motorbike, a motorbike tour rider or private car driver will take to to places you request, but i can't recommend any at the moment. all the riders i've used have found new jobs. the drivers i've used were sole operators and some have had to sell their cars. others decided not to continue to register it as a business car carrying the new yellow plates. maybe they will return sometime. meanwhile, they too have other work. your hotel will probably know who is available.
regards
rayza

column4:
dont case everyone hating saigon, contributors come "whole vietnam" experience see sinking whole week saigon wasted opportunity.
i saigon, large asian city days nice out. there's war museum, independence palace cu chi tunnels interest you, plus bunch lesser sites underground bunkers alleyway households.
if real buff, good leave saigon days, head quang tri province check vinh moc tunnels head khe sanh hills. plenty see area.
column5:
dont think it's a case of everyone hating saigon, more that most contributors come from a "whole of vietnam" experience and see sinking the whole of a week to just saigon as a wasted opportunity.
i like saigon, but it is a large asian city and after 3 or 4 days its nice to get out. there's a few things there like the war museum, the independence palace and the cu chi tunnels that will be of interest to you, plus a bunch of lesser sites like underground bunkers in alleyway households.
if you are a real buff, a good thing to do would be to leave saigon after 3 or 4 days, and head up to quang tri province and check out the vinh moc tunnels and maybe head over to khe sanh in the hills. plenty to see in this area.

column4:
kyoto obvious choice provided willing spend 28,000 yen roundtrip train. train ride takes 2.5 hours way.
if want spend kind money, two days, day trips closer tokyo. mt. fuji visit, head fuji five lakes. downside summer often hazy. haze, mist, clouds rain, see mountain. spending two days increases chances seeing mountain. also, july, kawaguchiko offers flower fields stunning lavender festival.
hakone mt. fuji area choice. view overall iconic ones fuji five lakes area makes cable car boat rides, volcanic valley steam, interesting themed museums.
both hakone fuji five lakes plenty onsen ryokans interested. try day tripper quick soak.
for smaller version "kyoto," kamakura historically significant temples shrines. trip often combined enoshima offers coastal views.
again, japan guide find more.
column5:
kyoto is the obvious choice provided you are willing to spend around 28,000 yen for a roundtrip on the train. the train ride takes about 2.5 hours one way.
if you don't want to spend that kind of money, with just two days, you can take day trips closer to tokyo. for a mt. fuji visit, head to fuji five lakes. the downside is summer is often hazy. if there is any haze, mist, clouds or rain, you won't see the mountain. spending two days there actually increases your chances of seeing the mountain. also, in july, kawaguchiko offers flower fields and a stunning lavender festival.
hakone is another mt. fuji area choice. the view overall is not as iconic as the ones from fuji five lakes but the area makes up for it with cable car and boat rides, a volcanic valley with steam, and some interesting themed museums.
both hakone and fuji five lakes have plenty of onsen ryokans if you are interested. you can also try some of them as a day tripper just for a quick soak.
for a smaller version of "kyoto," kamakura has historically significant temples and shrines. the trip is often combined with enoshima which offers coastal views.
again, use japan guide to find out more.

column5:
overall your itin looks fine.
for long distance travels in your itin, the 7-day national jr pass would payoff if you
a. activate it when departing to hakone
b. return to tokyo before it expires - thus shorten 1 night in either hakone or kyoto/osaka.
usage of jr pass.

for most visitors, an overnight in hakone would suffice, excluding museums' visits.
consider this odakyu hakone freepass which saves by completing the hakone loop once. in your case, buy it after arriving at odawara, ie. the cheaper option.

for daily commutes on city subways and commuter trains in japan, buy a prepaid suica / pasmo card to save the hassles of buying train tickets for every ride.

given 4 nights in tokyo, consider this tokyo 72-hour subway ticket which roughly payoff if you take at least 3 to 4 rides daily.

in kyoto/osaka, take city subways and commuter trains operated by jr, hankyu, keihan as much as possible to avoid traffic jams. use suica/pasmo for such.
if you hold a valid jr pass, then use it to ride jr commuter trains in tokyo, kyoto/osaka etc.
given 2 airports in tokyo, there are various means, ie. trains and limo bus to access to various parts of tokyo. search on japan-guide.com for details.
post again after you've roughly identified areas that you might stay and indicate your landing and departing airports.
as of now, planning is fine but better don't commit to any non-refundable air tickets, hotels until sep/oct and monitor if/when travel restrictions are lifted.

column4: adachi museum garden maintained perfectly, visitors allowed stroll garden. viewed windows museum building. fortunately, keep windows clean, views photos. middle dense city, distractions surrounding buildings, problem gardens larger cities. near matsue, castle, canals, historic district.
column5: the adachi museum garden is maintained perfectly, but visitors aren't allowed to stroll through the garden. it can be viewed only from the windows of the museum building. fortunately, they keep the windows clean, and you can get great views and photos. and because it's not in the middle of a dense city, there are no distractions from surrounding buildings, which are a problem with most of the gardens in larger cities. it's near matsue, which has a castle, canals, and a historic district.

column4:
possible plan based current allocation:
tokyo days--including day trip kawaguchiko hakone clear day. kawaguchigo gives mt. fuji view. hakone's various rides museums interesting child though. head kanazawa evening day 6.
kanazawa--if want move much, spend full day kanazawa. second day, 1/2 day trip shirakawago, spectacular village roughly 75 minutes away bus. spend half day kanazawa. want allocate 3rd day, onto takayama shirakawago instead spend day there.
kyoto--4 full days fine. spend 1/2 day nara morning early afternoon. quick visit osaka afterwards.
there lots lots possibilities depends whether want keep simple move more.
column5:
a possible plan based on your current allocation:
tokyo 6 days--including a day trip to kawaguchiko or hakone on a clear day. kawaguchigo gives the better mt. fuji view. hakone's various rides and museums might be more interesting for your child though. head for kanazawa on the evening of day 6.
kanazawa--if you don't want to move around too much, spend 1 full day at kanazawa. on the second day, take a 1/2 day trip to shirakawago, a spectacular village roughly 75 minutes away by bus. spend the other half day back at kanazawa. if you want to allocate a 3rd day, you can go onto takayama after shirakawago instead and spend day 3 there.
kyoto--4 full days should be fine. spend 1/2 day at nara one morning to early afternoon. you can take a quick visit to osaka afterwards.
there are lots and lots of other possibilities so it depends on whether you want to keep things simple or move around more.

i am traveling to japan, and as an interior designer i am interested in learning about japanese interior design history both old and new. anyone have any tips on either museums, places to visit, even courses to take on this subject?

column4: matsudo city, chiba prefecture, matsudo municipal museum includes replica interior postwar danchi apartment. see  . tokiwadaira danchi complex located south tokiwadaira station, across street seiyu store. there, looks interesting.
column5: in matsudo city, chiba prefecture, the matsudo municipal museum includes a replica of the interior of a postwar danchi apartment. see  . the tokiwadaira danchi complex is located south of tokiwadaira station, across the street from the seiyu store. i haven't been there, but it looks interesting.

column4:
history, recommend edo tokyo museum (tokyo), peace memorial museum (hiroshima), entire city kyoto. cultural history, tokyo national museum remarkable. keep mind extensive bombing major japanese cities world war ii, exception kyoto.
the baggage delivery services japan reliable. could plan travel light laundry often. low-priced business hotel chains toyoko inn, comfort hotel, superhotel coin-operated laundry machines guests use. rooms tiny, laughably tiny.
column5:
for history, i recommend the edo tokyo museum (tokyo), peace memorial museum (hiroshima), and the entire city of kyoto. for cultural history, the tokyo national museum is remarkable. keep in mind that there was extensive bombing of major japanese cities during world war ii, with the exception of kyoto.
the baggage delivery services in japan are reliable. you could also plan to travel light and do laundry often. low-priced business hotel chains like toyoko inn, comfort hotel, and superhotel have coin-operated laundry machines for guests to use. but their rooms are tiny, sometimes laughably tiny.

column5:
hi all,
so, should we be allowed into the country (we will be fully vaccinated by then but who can tell), my partner and i are planning a 3-week trip to japan for october 2021 (all of the below assumes relative normalcy, backup plan is us west coast if not, with this one then being parked until we can get over to japan).
neither of us have been before (in fact we haven't been further east than istanbul) and we may not be back for a long time. we also haven't been anywhere since nov 2019, so keen to make it a good one!
essential elements for the trip are:
guinea pig bridge (nagasaki bio park)
whale sharks (okinawa chaurami aquarium)
disneyland + disneysea (no weekends)
usj + halloween horror nights (no weekends)
studio ghibli museum
kobe beef (heavy preference for in kobe)
time-based events we would like to see (happy to take advice on what is "worth it" or may compromise seeing the rest of the towns in question):
yokohama oktoberfest, 3rd-19th
nagasaki festival, 7th-9th
onomichi lantern festival, 9th
takayama festival, 9th (though can't fit this in at present)
okinawa tug of war festival, 10th
himeji "fighting" festival, 15th
kurama fire festival, 22nd
less-specific goals:
visit all 4 major islands (+ okinawa)
see the autumn leaves (probably hokkaido due to dates)
see mt fuji (aware climbing is out)
see major sights of tokyo, kyoto, osaka
see as many other cultural sights as possible
shopping for retro video games/gear (i import and sell this stuff, so may as well pick some up while there if possible)
relevant interests:
animals (esp. sealife and small furry things)
scenic views
volcanoes, caves, other interesting geology
world war ii history
food (esp. seafood)
anime (esp. studio ghibli, nge, jba)
video games (esp. nintendo)
planes, trains (we work in those industries)
flight prices mean we can practically only have endpoints at tokyo and osaka (essentially tokyo), and we plan to arrive (from the uk) on the evening of 3rd oct, departing late in the evening of 23rd oct. travel in between will be primarily by train (shinkansen/sunrise express mostly), taking advantage of the okinawa flights to get to hokkaido and avoid one long train leg.

column4:
see  . yokohama port piers: shinko, osanbashi, daikoku. shinko osanbashi conveniently located within walking distance minato mirai redevelopment area. daikoku conveniently located. cruise line able tell pier use, port reassign boat closer time trip.
yokohama chinatown different san francisco chinatown, plenty yokohama. minato mirai area, there's plenty shopping, yokohama museum art, japanese overseas migration museum. street view function google maps "preview" chinatown minato mirai district. elsewhere yokohama, there's sankeien garden. train service (including english signage) yokohama tokyo excellent, trains crowded commute hours. schedules, see www.hyperdia.com. yokohama, easy day trip kamakura. i'm big fan yokohama, want spend time tokyo, sense stay tokyo.
in general, hotels cheaper yokohama tokyo. couple low-priced toyoko inns adjacent baseball stadium yokohama, many hotels kannai station waterfront.
column5:
please see  . the yokohama port has 3 piers: shinko, osanbashi, and daikoku. shinko and osanbashi are conveniently located within walking distance of the minato mirai redevelopment area. daikoku is not conveniently located. your cruise line may be able to tell you which pier they will use, but the port might reassign the boat closer to the time of your trip.
yokohama chinatown is not that different from san francisco chinatown, but there are plenty of other things to do in yokohama. in the minato mirai area, there's plenty of shopping, the yokohama museum of art, and the japanese overseas migration museum. you can use the street view function on google maps to "preview" chinatown and the minato mirai district. elsewhere in yokohama, there's the sankeien garden. train service (including english signage) from yokohama to tokyo is excellent, although trains are crowded during commute hours. for schedules, see www.hyperdia.com. from yokohama, it would be easy to do a day trip to kamakura. i'm a big fan of yokohama, but if you want to spend most of your time in tokyo, it might make sense to stay in tokyo.
in general, hotels may be cheaper in yokohama than in tokyo. there are a couple of low-priced toyoko inns adjacent to the baseball stadium in yokohama, and there are many other hotels between kannai station and the waterfront.

column5:
hello everyone,
it's been a long time since i've visited japan, was an english teacher there for a couple years in mie prefecture (2014 - 2016). i've been wanting to bring my fiance their to give her a bit of my experience, and have been planning a trip back for some time. i wanted to get out to areas i didn't get to visit while there, but also hit up some of the major tourist attractions for her, and was curious if we may be moving too fast over the course of the trip. i took inspiration from the hokuriku arch pass guide from japan-guide.com here:

this is a rough guide to what i've planned out, and have friends i'll be staying with in both tokyo and nagoya. everywhere else we'll be staying at ryokan, or hotels.
depart on nov. 6th
tokyo nov. 7 - 9th
ghibli museum, akihabara, senso-ji, ooedo onsen
one full day in kamakura (probably the 9th)
omiya bonsai museum, ikaho onsen town - 10th
jigokudani monkey park, shiba onsen town - 11th
kurobe gorge, kuronagi onsen ryokan - 12th
shirakawa-go, takayama - 13th
takayama morning markets, kanazawa day trip, night in kyoto - 14th
kyoto, osaka by nightfall - 15th
koyasan - 16th
koyasan, nara, nagoya by nightfall - 17th
tsu, ise, toba (where i taught), nagoya stay - 18th
kiso valley, night bus to tokyo - 19th
tokyo - 20th
tokyo, depart at 6:20pm flight - 21
any thoughts on this? have i planned too much? also if anyone has any advice on booking tickets now, or when would be an opportune time to wait. tickets right now during that time period are around $570 - 600 round trip, and would love to book, but expect things may not improve in japan by then.
thanks!
