column5:
in addition to the reasons of interest for the discovery, mentioned in the bbc article, at least one more can be mentioned.
the huge sulawesi island (formerly known as celebes), place of the findings, and of which the greatest reason for notoriety is probably given by the singular funerary customs of the toraja population, is part of the archipelagic complex called by paleontologists "wallacea", of interest as used by the first men to make the long amphibious journey from continental asia to what will finally be the first settlement of oceania (where, as is well known, humanity landed long before the americas).
moreover, the finds of hominids that have not left graphic traces are much older in sulawesi, up to well over 100,000 years ago.
the newspapers that have reported the news so far, regarding the location of the caves decorated with drawings, and in particular of the most cited, the leang tedongnge cave, about the locatin just inform that it's in the south of sulawesi, and "at least an hour walk from the nearest carriage road" (which actually doesn't seem much to me).
however, better information on the location can be obtained from the map which is on page 2 of the article that gave the scientific information on the findings

from such map it's clear that the caves are located on the east-northeast of the city of maros, at a distance of at least 20 kms.
overall, we don't know when (or even if) these findings will be accessible to the public; but in the meantime, it's useful, for the traveler who is in or passes through maros, to be aware that in the area a fundamental episode of mankind's initial march towards the settlement of the whole planet is witnessed.

column5:
in 2015 we had a brilliant visit to japan, basing ourselves in tokyo and then kyoto around the beginning of the cherry blossom season, and visiting nikko, nara, hiroshima, hikone.
while there is no doubt loads more to see in both kyoto and tokyo, where would you recommend for a second visit? we'll be two adults, and we really enjoyed:
* travelling by train
* onsen
* japanese food
* historic buildings and sites
* gardens
* blossom
* the former tsukiji fish market
* tokyo art museums
we'd be looking at travelling in the autumn (probably no sooner than 2022 given covid, but it would be good to have something to look forward to) so we can see the autumn colour.
while we'd be flying from the uk, i'd prefer not to fly internally in japan if it can be avoided - so i wouldn't be looking to visit the far south and far north in one visit!
column8: Recommendations for a second visit to Japan

column4:
japan fabulous train system! could national regional rail passes travel throughout japan. details passes posted japan-guide.com.
places consider visiting:
the tohoku region (north tokyo), including matsushima, hiraizumi, kakunodate.
takamatsu (ritsurin garden, shikoku mura, ferry naoshima "art island")
arita (in saga prefecture) porcelain
kagoshima (sengan-en garden, museum meiji restoration, side trip chiran peace museum kamikaze pilots)
matsue (historic district, lafcadio hearn museum, castle, side trip garden adachi museum)
column5:
japan has a fabulous train system! you could use one or more national or regional rail passes to travel throughout japan. details about the passes are posted at japan-guide.com.
places to consider visiting:
the tohoku region (north of tokyo), including matsushima, hiraizumi, and kakunodate.
takamatsu (ritsurin garden, shikoku mura, ferry to naoshima "art island")
arita (in saga prefecture) for porcelain
kagoshima (sengan-en garden, museum of the meiji restoration, and a side trip to chiran for the peace museum for kamikaze pilots)
matsue (historic district, lafcadio hearn museum, castle, and a side trip to the garden at adachi museum)
column8: Recommendations for a second visit to Japan

column5:
i have a weak back, so i can't carry a full book with me all day. so i neatly cut out the pages i'll need for the day and carry only those pages in my backpack.
try to include a few places in your itinerary that are not included in your guidebooks or get very little attention from guidebooks. maybe some quirky little museum or small town that you hear about in a posting on this forum. it's always fun when a local person asks you, "how did you find this place?"

column4: certainly possible see peace memorial museum miyajima day, want linger among memorials park surrounds museum. rushed, time visit exhibit space former bank japan building, little museum fukuromachi elementary school, shukkei-en garden, mitaki temple, museum contemporary art. advise two days leisurely experience, consider length trip number places want visit. many trips japan, personal rule stay least nights city.
column5: it's certainly possible to see the peace memorial museum and miyajima in the same day, but you might want to linger among the memorials in the park that surrounds the museum. if you're rushed, you won't have time to visit the exhibit space at the former bank of japan building, the little museum at the fukuromachi elementary school, the shukkei-en garden, mitaki temple, or the museum of contemporary art. i would advise two days for a more leisurely experience, but you will have to consider the length of your trip and the number of places you want to visit. after many trips to japan, my personal rule is to always stay at least 2 nights in any city.

column5:
welcome, segmn, to the japan forums.
"we would be overnighting spending the whole next day and spend that night as well."
where are you planning to overnight - hiroshima or miyajima?
i agree with bargainhunter, there is plenty to see in hiroshima: in addition to the peace museum, you shouldn't miss shukkei-en garden surrounding the art museum there, and mitaki-dera.
same for miyajima, once you get off the tourist street of shops there is plenty to see besides the obvious, you can hike up mt misen, and you definitely shouldn't miss daisho-in.
we too hate one-nighters as bargainhunter says and we choose to stay 2 nights at the very minimum but prefer 3 or more wherever we visit.
so yes, as dr s says, it can be done, would we do it? no.
hfot2

column5:
i know, you didn’t put forward singapore as an option, but consider flying via singapore.
you can take a bus over the border to legoland malaysia for the day from singapore. or stay over night in the legoland hotel. lots of fun and sunshine.
myself, i would choose via tokyo due to the better airlines, ana or japan airlines. there is hello kitty land and disneyland in tokyo too. narita town is beautiful for its temples, gardens and small village feel. it will involve a lot of walking for the children.
for kuala lumpur, the petronas twin towers is exciting, the bird park and butterfly park especially great for small children. hotels, food and travel(taxi) is less than half the cost of singapore and tokyo due to the exchange rate. tokyo, singapore, kl ranking for safety respectively 1(best), 3, 7 just imho.

column4:
feel unsafe kl all. said, agree japan interesting.
if choose tokyo, days, fly nrt, stay narita city. ueno optimal choice straightforward express train ride nrt airport. ueno served jr, including convenient yamanote line. subway lines access. fly hnd, central western part tokyo convenient.

column5:
i don't feel unsafe in kl at all. that said, i agree japan is more interesting.
if you choose tokyo, since you have 3 days, even if you fly into nrt, don't stay at narita city. ueno might be the optimal choice since it's a straightforward express train ride from nrt airport. ueno is also served by jr, including the convenient yamanote line. you will also have subway lines access. if you fly into hnd, then most of central to the western part of tokyo is convenient.
for the kids, you could consider disneysea which offers something unique. don't go to disneyland though since you can visit the one in france. personally, i wouldn't worry too much about what they are interested in all the time. explore together so all of you experience something new.

column5:
instead of borough market again, switch days and try one of the weekend markets... broadway or maltby street. or head to one of the daily marketplaces like brixton market or brick lane. (if you visit brixton market, grab a snack at wings 'n' tings... delicious!)
i second the recommendation for the imperial war museum. there's a wwi gallery that might be eye-opening for the kids, since that war isn't really taught or talked about in the us.
(by the way, in dublin, be sure to visit the epic irish emigration museum. it's a fascinating look at the irish diaspora, and if you have irish ancestors, you can make an appointment to have someone help you research them.)
edited: 6:01 am, may 31, 2021

column4:
tank museum, need train waterloo wool via bournemouth, 2.5hr, taxi wool museum. time year, best prebook taxi.
just aware train splits bournemouth front portion travelling weymouth/wool, listen announcements train.
also aware wool station minimal facilities - including waiting room - cold, dark miserable cafe bunker in. i'd dress accordingly!
column5:
for the tank museum, you'll need a train from waterloo to wool via bournemouth, which will take about 2.5hr, and then a taxi from wool to the museum. at that time of year, it's probably best to prebook the taxi.
just be aware that the train sometimes splits at bournemouth with only the front portion travelling on to weymouth/wool, so listen for announcements on the train.
also be aware that wool station has minimal facilities - including no waiting room - so if it's cold, dark and miserable there isn't even a cafe to bunker down in. i'd dress accordingly!

column5:
thoughts about places to just wander unplanned - the covent garden/seven dials area has a lot of nooks and crannies that are good for a wander - and try neal’s yard for cheese too.
the walk along the south bank, particularly between london and waterloo bridges always has things going on.
you don’t seem to have been up high for a view yet - rather than the expense of the shard, book when tickets open for your trip to visit skygarden for free.
and you haven’t listed a visit to either westminster abbey or st paul’s? personally i prefer the latter, but the former has centuries of british history within its walls.
i’d also suggest the sons do some of the research, because they may have other preferences! if you want to really spend hours in the british museum (easy to do) and they don’t, maybe agree they’ll go off and do their own thing after a quick trip round the highlights with you.

column5:
thanks everybody for your suggestions. after going through them and doing my own research, i changed my mind a little and came up with the below plan. we will be staying 3d2n in glasgow and 1n1d in edinburgh.
we could not consider a timberbush tour as their tours are cancelled on the days we’ll be in glasgow. could you please review the plan and let me know your suggestions?
1. day 1: we will be reaching glasgow at around 2 pm. is it possible to cover loch lomond and trossachs national park with public transport during rest of the day? i found we can take the train to balloch and get into sweeny’s cruise for a circular tour of loch lomond. but what about trossachs national park? is its entrance also near balloch station? are we better off going by bus if we plan to cover both? please advise.
2. day 2: day return trip by train from glasgow to mallaig via fort william. i know we will spend 10+ hours in train, but we find the opportunity to experience one of the most scenic routes in the world hard to resist. besides the kids also love train ride, so i believe they will not complain.
3. day 3: this is where i am still undecided. this will be our last day in glasgow and we’re considering a day trip to one of these locations by public transport: isle of arran/ayrshire coast/stirling castle/oban/inverness/st andrews. which one of these do you suggest we should go assuming we will never visit scotland again? :-). we should be ok as long as we return to glasgow by 9 pm. will take the next train to edinburgh that night.
4. day 4: explore edinburgh, of course including the royal mile and edinburgh castle. do you think we can visit arthur’s seat too with the kids? if not, any other suggestion (not too keen on visiting museums)? we have a return train to catch from edinburgh station at around 6 pm. so any suggestions to spend the day in edinburgh will be appreciated.

column4:
three nights two full days cornwall. staying marazion enough area fill days. day could lizard visiting cadgwith, lizard village kynance cove - pasties ann’s bakery lizard village. day could newlyn, mousehole, sennen (walk land’s end miss worst tacky theme park closed), cape cornwall botallack iconic buildings (this area opinion far atmospheric interesting land’s end).
if choose st ives, don’t try drive old part town. park leisure centre walk bus town usually recommend park ride amazing train journey public transport avoided unless necessary.
for journey towards cornwall could spend time dartmoor suggested visit lost gardens heligan must prebooked.
you able see st michael’s mount marazion island closed visitors.
as mentioned previously roads cornwall narrow passing places reversing required meet someone. don’t try drive old harbour villages:cadgwith, mousehole, port isaac built cars invented.
edited: 7:44 pm, april 08,
column5:
three nights is only two full days in cornwall. as you are staying in marazion you will have enough to do in that area to fill your days. one day could be on the lizard visiting cadgwith, lizard village and kynance cove - great pasties from ann’s bakery in lizard village. the other day could be newlyn, mousehole, sennen (walk to land’s end from there and you will miss the worst of the tacky theme park although that is closed), then cape cornwall and botallack with its iconic mine buildings (this area in my opinion is far more atmospheric and interesting than land’s end).
if you choose to go to st ives, don’t try to drive in the old part of the town. you can park at the leisure centre and either walk or take the bus into the town i usually recommend the park and ride for an amazing train journey but public transport is still to be avoided unless necessary.
for your journey towards cornwall you could either spend time on dartmoor as suggested above or visit the lost gardens of heligan but that must be prebooked.
you will be able to see st michael’s mount from marazion but the island is closed to visitors.
as mentioned previously some of the roads in cornwall are very narrow with passing places so reversing may be required if you meet someone. don’t try to drive into the old harbour villages:cadgwith, mousehole, port isaac etc as they were built before cars were invented.
edited: 7:44 pm, april 08, 2021

column4:
dumfries & galloway due move level restrictions june theory means many places able open visitors best check advance case booking required.
if car serviced want walk river nith - burns visitor centre far side town, accessible suspension footbridge old stone footbridge alongside weir. centre bistro - called jaggy thistle. i've visited recently recent incarnation fares. cavens arms within walking distance buccleuch street bar meals. edenbank hotel far side river hill stone bridge crossing usually nice meal. (you need directions find tucked away residential area).
likewise visiting moat brae (peter pan link) directions tucked away, museum/camera obscura far side river.
there lots cafes high street overly attractive comparison many years ago many independent shops replaced charity shops vacant ones.
column5:
dumfries & galloway is due to move into level 1 restrictions on 5 june which in theory means many places should be able to open for visitors however best to check in advance in case booking is required.
if your car is being serviced you may just want to have a walk around by the river nith - the burns visitor centre is on the far side from the town, accessible by a suspension footbridge or an old stone footbridge alongside the weir. the centre has a bistro - now called the jaggy thistle. i've not visited recently so don't know how this most recent incarnation fares. there is the the cavens arms within walking distance on buccleuch street which does bar meals. the edenbank hotel on the far side of the river and up the hill from the stone bridge crossing usually does a nice meal. (you would need to have directions to find it as it is tucked away in a residential area).
likewise if visiting moat brae (peter pan link) get your directions as it is tucked away, as is the museum/camera obscura on the far side of the river.
there are lots of cafes in and around in the high street although that is not overly attractive in comparison to how it was many years ago as many independent shops have been replaced by charity shops and vacant ones.

column4: there's art gallery llandudno (oriel mostyn) place called home front museum dedicated second world war life 1940s. ten minutes away conwy there's plas mawr (a fully restored elizabethan town house), aberconwy house (a medieval merchants house) royal cambrian art gallery. there's smallest house britain quay, queue ideal raining.
column5: there's an art gallery in llandudno (oriel mostyn) and a place called home front which is a museum dedicated to the second world war and life in the 1940s. ten minutes away in conwy there's plas mawr (a fully restored elizabethan town house), aberconwy house (a medieval merchants house) and the royal cambrian art gallery. there's also the smallest house in great britain on the quay, although you might have to queue to get in which might not be ideal if it's raining.

column5:
i've been going back and forth on here and elsewhere on the internet trying to make sense of the oyster travelcard that can be added to the london pass.
initially we thought that it was an unlimited travel pass, but no, it has limits. a three-day travelcard comes with a 25 pound credit, and the site says, as an example, that there's a capped daily limit for zones 1 - 2 of 7 pounds. then after we've exceeded the cap it's all free! so do i take it that as long as we stay in zones 1 - 2 we can go back and forth as much as we please on the transport system and all that will be deducted per day from our running total of 25 pounds will be 7 pounds? if we do that for the first two days there'll be 11 pounds left on day three, and as we'd planned on starting out the day by going out to hampton court palace, which is in zone 6, we'll get charged 12.80 pounds, which would mean having to top up the card by 1.80 - or whatever the minimum increment is - to make it work? does it mean we can still go back and forth in zones 1 - 2 for the day once we get back from hampton court?
we're trying to figure out our best options, particularly as we'll actually be in london for four days, not three. the first day we were going to focus on the free museums and wear the cost directly for the 2 - 3 trains we'll likely catch getting about, then use the london pass and associated travelcard for the next three days.
we were planning on a four-day stay in london, the first of which was going to take in the free museums. then for the last three days we were going to use the passes.

column5:
actually i hunted around everywhere on here trying to get the answer for the travel card, but nothing seemed to clearly answer the question on how the daily limits work - most of the questions were about which options to use for public transport around london. both my wife and i kept getting thrown off by the point about reaching a daily limit, after which it's free - to me it kept reading like they were saying it was an unlimited pass, so why the point about charging 7 pounds for zones 1 - 2, as an example? we finally figured it out (i think!) but the wording could be better for those not familiar with the system.
also, judging from some of the answers, people are making assumptions, or misunderstood the wording of my post - i was only ever asking for answers pertaining to the travel card. i lived in london back in the early 80's (well before the oyster cards came along) and have been back twice since then. my wife has also lived in the uk, though this will be the first time we'll be going there together. so for us this will be a case of going over familiar territory - other than hampton court palace, which for some reason or another i never got around to seeing before. so we are pretty familiar with everything on our list, and are basically visiting them as old friends - i've been to the tower three times, as an example, once on my own in the 80's, and again when i've taken each of our children to london on subsequent visits.
in our case the london pass work out well for this visit as we don't need to dwell interminably at places like the tower, having done it before, nor the british museum, but can just do a 'greatest hits' visit for old time's sake, like the rosetta stone and the elgian marbles.
i've already totaled up the individual ticket prices and they come to considerably more than the cost of the london pass, so in our case it's well worth it, and it does throw in some bonuses that i otherwise wouldn't have considered. when i'm at the tower i always make a point of crossing tower bridge while i'm in the area, but with the london pass we'll get the opportunity to actually climb up and go across the glass-floored walkways, something which i ordinarily wouldn't have considered. the shard has also opened since my last visit to london, and as a student of architecture (i visited the burj khalifa about 18 months ago) i would have visited it with or without the london pass, but with the pass i save over 30 pounds on the ticket, which is a considerable amount given that a 3-day london pass (with the current discount) comes in at 113 pounds. because we've been to london before i was also planning on mixing in a few novelty things this time around like a few movie sites, abbey road, lords cricket ground museum, etc - i'm actually twisting my wife's arm to add another day to our visit to give us more time for that side of things.
judging from a number of posts i've seen in this forum, it seems to be fashionable among some to scorn the london pass when in actual fact it represents good value, especially if used judiciously. unlike places like paris, london offers up a plethora of world-class (and time consuming) museums that are free, and for those looking to get value for money a day or two spent getting those out of the way first (or last) then using the london pass to save on other sites, would work out well. the tower, westminster abbey, st. paul's, hampton court palace, and the shard are but five main sites around london that in total would cost more to visit separately then the cost of the 3-day london pass. throw in other sites such as a cruise on the thames, windsor, kensington palace, tower bridge, greenwich, the globe, london zoo, etc, as well as sundry bonuses such as movie tickets and guided walking tours, and there's considerable value to be had from the pass from morning through to mid evening, though of course you wouldn't be able to see all the places i just mentioned in three days unless you pushed to extremes! it's just a case of how well you apply it without going overboard trying to squeeze it to the max allowed. in our case there's a 400 pound limit on a three-day pass, and our total on the things we've planned for comes in at around 320 pounds. not bad on a pass that comes in at about a third of the price.
our planned trip involves a four-day stay in london and five days in paris, and on that score i'd say the exact opposite for the latter, as the equivalent pass for paris gives the user next to no value at all when it comes to the bread and butter places most visitors want to see - its only value comes with all the extras thrown in for things like wine-tasting, a perfume museum, and so on, places that people wouldn't ordinarily consider for a visit. for paris it's much better value to skip the paris pass and just buy the far less costly paris museum pass - as i said, unlike london very few sites in paris are free, with the rare exceptions being places such as sacre couer and pere lachaise cemetery.
the thing with passes is to just do your homework and not go overboard and greedy in planning for their use. i only recently got back from a visit to egypt where they offer a cairo pass and a luxor pass, and they're brilliant value (when you can find them - it's almost like a state secret trying to buy them!) though with cairo's appalling traffic it's harder to get the best value out of the cairo pass. where it really shines though is that it entitles the bearer to buy the luxor premium pass at 50% of the face value ($100 instead of $200) which is almost a steal when one considers that visiting the amazing tombs of nefertari and seti i normally comes in at $50 each - and with the pass you can visit them as often as you like within the three-day limit. throw in karnak, luxor temple, the other tombs in the valley of the kings, etc and the two passes represent great value.

column5:
"what is really worth paying to go inside"
this is a matter of personal taste. out of london's paid attractions, my favourites are westminster abbey and st paul's cathedral. but i am sure that there are some people that prefer madam tussauds, which i have never visited.
i can also add that some of my favourite attractions in london such as the national gallery, the natural history museum and the british museum are free. frankly it is a mistake to make the london pass your starting point. it is entirely possible to have a very busy 2 days in london without paying a single admission fee.

column4:
drive bath liverpool start early goes cotswolds stops s-o-a.
i expect coach come m62 quick drive forthlin road, mendips penny lane dropping hard days night hotel, decent hotel city centre centre corner "new" cavern club mathew street.
but lucky got 4pm, time going dark time explore rest liverpool (the two cathedrals, pier head albert dock, museums galleries etc).
then crack dawn drive lake district.
column5:
the drive from bath to liverpool would have to start early as it goes through the cotswolds and stops off at s-o-a.
i expect the coach will come off the m62 and do a quick drive by of forthlin road, mendips and penny lane before dropping you off at the hard days night hotel, which is actually a decent hotel in the city centre centre around the corner from the "new" cavern club on mathew street.
but you'd be lucky if you got there before 4pm, by which time it will be going dark and you won't have time to explore the rest of liverpool (the two cathedrals, the pier head and albert dock, the museums and galleries etc).
then it will be up at the crack of dawn for the drive to the lake district.

looks people commented understanding program. watched it?
tiger zoos thailand usually zoos name. fact tiger farms.
the farms supply illegal trade animal parts consumed manly vietnam china, thailand laos..
these "farms" business supplying tigers ... dead alive. program points cubs farm. farms often little cub factories. speed-breeding techniques number frequency cubs produced shipped out/sold tourist attractions.
so pet baby tiger zoo thailand overriding chances come tiger farm.
interaction captive tigers essentially relies tiger farms maintain supply cuddle cubs pet.
column5:
it looks as if people have commented without understanding the program. maybe they haven't watched it?
tiger zoos in thailand are usually only zoos by name. they are in fact tiger farms.
the farms supply the illegal trade in animal parts which are consumed manly in vietnam and china, but also in thailand and laos..
these "farms" are in the business of supplying tigers ... dead or alive. as the program points out their were no cubs in one farm. these farms are often little more than cub factories. they use speed-breeding techniques to up the number and frequency of cubs produced and then they are shipped out/sold to other tourist attractions.
so when you pet a baby tiger in any zoo in thailand the overriding chances are that it has come from a tiger farm.
interaction with captive tigers essentially relies on tiger farms to maintain a supply of cuddle cubs to pet.

column5:
it has been mentioned that covid means the trade has reduced. ...e.g. demand in china/vietnam for wild animals overall has dropped ... this isn't entirely true - it has caused all sorts of problems. some zoos are unable to look after there ill-gotten charges. the temptation for some is to kill and butcher tigers that can't be kept. cub breeding may have reduced as they might be too old to display to the public by the time the foreigners return. however, the program shows that the zoos have targeted to thai population to keep some visitor numbers.
whatever the effects of covidhiatus, they are not permanent. as tourist numbers increase, so the zoos will attempt to regenerate business - and will need an assured endless supply of cubs.
the coup in burma has also increased to chances for poachers and smugglers.
there is at present a chance for the thai authorities to step in and prevent a resurgence of this sordid trade....unfortunately it seems they don't have the will or even the knowledge to deal with it.

column5:
so a european equivalent trip would be taking in athens, dubrovnik, rome maybe taking in venice and florence ending up in barcelona and perhaps ibiza and taking in a beach en route plus a zoo !
well you could do the european one with an under 26 rail rover pass sleeping on the trains but you fail the age class and likewise your asian adventure will have you spending many a happy hour in departure lounges and cities. -
in a nutshell i think you are trying to do too much but suggest you go on skyscanner and air asia websites to see who flies where although with the current situation we don't know when if ever anything like precovid travel will be permitted and althouth the uk will be vaccinated up by say august i doubt laos will be by the end of this year and thailand may if they are lucky have 60% vaccinated this year.
you are on the thailand forum so it goes without saying i would suggest you cut out kl and penang although both are worth a visit just sticking to two countries will make it easier and again you have got half the country on your wish list.
i am not going to suggest an itinery as if you use the advance search box /youtube you cn find out more than enough on getting around but my general advice is simplify your trip.
